(Emphasis added).

Ms Wong's stated in evidence she updated the file note "with the information provided to [her] by [Mr] Sant to ensure that a permanent record was kept" and that the marginal notes (being the notes which appear in the transcript under the heading "Notes on left hand corner") were added up to a year after the 22 August 2006 meeting.
I accept that the marginal notes were a much later addition.

In my view, in addition to the marginal notes, the phrase "appears to be comparable to other enquiries at QV / Target" which I have italicised in the extract (see [92] above) was also a later addition.
I reject Ms Wong's evidence that at the meeting on 22 August 2006 she had the information recorded in the marginal notes.
In fact, at one point in her evidence, Ms Wong conceded she did not obtain the shop numbers that appear in the marginal notes until some time in 2007.

Ms Wong's evidence in relation to where and when she obtained the information recorded in the marginal notes was not corroborated by the evidence from Mr Hii or Mr Sant and was inconsistent with a report Ms Wong prepared in June 2007.
Moreover, the form and substance of the note itself is not consistent with Ms Wong having the information in the marginal notes at the meeting on 22 August 2006.
Mr Hii's viva voce evidence on this issue was inconsistent with his sworn affidavit.
The paragraph of his affidavit concerning the information recorded in the marginal notes was identical in form and substance to the contents of Ms Wong's affidavit on that issue.
It was as if the paragraph had been cut and pasted from one affidavit to the other.

That conclusion is supported by the fact that during the course of his viva voce evidence, Mr Hii said he had no recollection of Ms Wong informing him of the details set out in the marginal notes (in particular the dimensions or shop number of the shops listed) at the meeting on 22 August 2006.
That is not surprising.

Although Ms Wong repeatedly said she believed she obtained the shop numbers from Mr Sant prior to the meeting in August 2006, his evidence was not only that he did not give the shop numbers to her at that time but that he did not know any of the numbers and that the shops did not have numbers on them.
In relation to the size or areas of the shops referred to in the marginal notes, Mr Sant's evidence again contradicted Ms Wong's affidavit evidence.
Mr Sant's evidence was that he did not give Ms Wong any information about the areas of the shops.
Finally, again contradicting Ms Wong's affidavit evidence, Mr Sant said that he did not provide Ms Wong with any information in 2006 about a bagel shop or Kentucky Fried Chicken at QV.

Taken at its highest, Mr Sant's evidence was that in 2006 he had obtained the following information: in relation to the Zest Wraps food outlet in QV, that tenant was paying between $55,000 and $60,000 per annum.
He had no information about area or the shop number.
in relation to Donut King food outlet in the Target Centre, that tenant was paying around $70,000 per annum.
Again, he had no other information about that tenancy.

Ms Wong also stated in her evidence that Mr Sant provided her with further information in 2007 which "reconfirmed" the information she had at the meeting on 22 August 2006 and which she included in the marginal notes on the file note one year later.
This evidence was also contradicted by Mr Sant.
His evidence was that Ms Wong did not ask him in 2007 to make enquiries at QV or at the Target Centre and that he did not give Ms Wong any information in 2007 about those centres.

The conclusion that in August 2006, or even June 2007, Ms Wong did not have the information in the marginal notes is also supported by emails between Ms Wong and Mr Tony Tai ("Mr Tai") of TT Global in late June 2007 and the contents of a submission Ms Wong prepared in June 2007 concerning the rent for a number of shops in the Food Court at the Paramount Centre.
On 20 June 2007, Ms Wong sent an email to Mr Tai entitled "Re Shop rent".

The email stated: 
Just a quick email re shop Star Walk and another one at The Walk.
I would still like to include them on my submission as a back up --- to show that foodcourt outlets are more expensive than stand alone shops.
Eg QV foodcourt --- Zest Wraps $50,000 pa for 25 sqm (No outgoings).
Target Centre --- Donut King $52,000 pa for 23 sqm (No outgoings).
Galleria Foodcourt up to $2200 per sqm plus $11/sq m outgoings.
Can you advise re name of shop, sq m and annual rental and outgoings.
Thanks for your help, Tony.

Mr Tai responded the next day in the following terms: 
Pat
 
 
Details for Star Walk Café is as follows:
 
 
SIZE = 91 M2
 
RENT = $100,000 (+GST) per annum gross
 
MARKETING LEVY = $2,000 (+GST) per annum gross
 
LEASE COMMENCEMENT DATE = 2/1/2006
 
LEASE TERM = 5 + 5 Years
 
RENT REVIEWS = CPI annually, Market @ Option
 
 The information provided to Mr Tai did not include the details set out in the marginal notes --- details that Ms Wong apparently regarded as critical to the submission she was then drafting.
Moreover, it is apparent that the response from Mr Tai did not appear to support her contention that "foodcourt outlets are more expensive than stand alone shops".
In fact, the information in Mr Tai's email of 21 June 2007 (see [99]) was included, in almost exactly the same terms, in Ms Wong's note allegedly dated 12 July 2006.
The '12 July 2006' note was the subject of cross examination and re-examination.
It seems highly unlikely that Ms Wong had the information on 12 July 2006 and her explanation of why she needed to reconfirm the information in 2007 should be rejected.
If, as Ms Wong asserted she had the precise information in 2006, why would she need to request that information again in 2007.
None of the lease details would have changed --- the lease for the Star Walk Café commenced in January 2006, was for a term of 5 years with annual rent increases fixed at CPI.

During the course of re-examination, in an apparent attempt to explain away the fact that she did not need to reconfirm the information, Ms Wong said that she sought details of an "another tenancy" that was unspecified.
I reject that evidence.
The submission drafted by Ms Wong for Dukemaster is dated 21 June 2007.

It was provided by Ms Wong to Mr Sheehan who had been nominated in June 2007 by the Victorian Small Business Commissioner to determine the current market rent of shops 1, 2, 4, 9 and 10 in the Food Court at the Paramount Centre.
It will be necessary to return to consider the submission and the determinations in further detail later in these reasons for decision.
For present purposes, it is sufficient to note that Ms Wong's submission did not include the information in the marginal notes.

Under the heading "Market Rental Indications", the submission stated: 
 From our associations with some of the estate agents and takeaway stores in other food courts, we have been advised the following rental indications .
We believe these food court outlets are very comparable to those at The Paramount Centre.

Galleria Food Court --- Jones Lang LaSalle (leasing agent) 
 
 
The outlets there average $1700 per sq m and some outlets as high as $2200 per sq m. There are outgoings ($11 per sq m) to be paid for each store.

Checked with some store operators there, was advised a store of about 25 --- 30 sq m paid about $60000 per annum (about $2000 to $2400 per sq m).

We also have the honour of knowing some operators with stand alone café/takeaways i.e.

not in food court environment and for the benefit of comparisons to stress the point that a food court outlet is more valuable than stand alone café in terms of rent due to common area environment as well as provision of amenities and facilities by centre management.

We provide the following:

(Emphasis added).
During the course of her evidence, Ms Wong admitted that it was "a certainty" she would have included the information in the marginal notes in the submission if she had had the information.
That admission was inevitable.

The information in the marginal notes was not only relevant to the submission but, if available at the time Ms Wong drafted the submission, was central to Dukemaster's position given the way in which Dukemaster responded to Mr Sheehan and ultimately conducted its defence of these proceedings.
It was the only evidence about comparable market rents in other food courts said by Dukemaster to exist in the period prior to June 2007.
The difficulty is that the evidence did not exist prior to June 2007.

If the information in the marginal notes did not exist in June 2006 (as I have found), then there was also no basis or reason for the inclusion of the phrase "appears to be comparable to other enquiries at QV / Target" in the 22 August 2006 note.
The form of the 22 August 2006 note itself provides further evidence that that phrase was a later addition.
A spare line exists between each numbered paragraph except between paragraphs (2) and (3) where the italicised phrase appears.
I find that the phrase was added after 22 August 2006 and more likely "up to a year after" that meeting.

Finally, the form and substance of the balance of the 22 August 2006 note itself (and the form and content of Ms Wong's submission to Mr Sheehan in June 2007) is not consistent with Ms Wong having the information in the marginal notes at the meeting on 22 August 2006.

In relation to the Bourke Street Rental and the Upper Bourke Street Rental, the 22 August 2006 note records not only that Ms Wong made enquiries of a Tony Tai, a real estate agent, but what his advice was and that she passed that advice on to Mr Hii.

If Ms Wong had the information in the marginal notes at the time of the 22 August 2006 meeting, you would have expected her not only to inform Mr Hii of that advice (which she did not) but also the source of it and to record those matters in the note at or soon after the meeting.
That is consistent with what Ms Wong did in the June 2007 submission to Mr Sheehan as seen by the italised sections of the extract of the submission at [101] above.
Not only is the information then in her possession clearly identified in a methodical and systematic manner but also the source of each piece of information is dealt with in the same manner.
Before leaving the information said to have been held by Dukemaster relating to comparable rents in 2006 and 2007, it is necessary to deal with two further handwritten notes.
The first note, also prepared by Ms Wong, bears the date "18/7/06" in the top left hand corner.
The opening words of the note are "Robert Sant reported the following findings from his survey".
The note goes on to record an alleged survey by Mr Sant of "Donut King" trading at the Target Centre in Bourke Street and "Zest Wraps" trading at QV.
Ms Wong gave evidence that the note was in a file she had with her at the 22 August 2006 meeting.
I reject that evidence.
The contents of the note are not consistent with the information in the marginal notes (see [92] above) or with Mr Sant's evidence (see [96] and [97] above).
In my view, the note was prepared in July 2007.
The details recorded in the handwritten note were reproduced in Dukemaster's submission to Mr Sheehan (see [101] above) in June 2007.
The year in the date on the original note appears to have been written over --- as if the "6" was later imposed.

Whether that is so, however, is not determinative because I find that Ms Wong did not have all of the information recorded in these notes available to her in June 2006 and that the note records at least enquiries made in June 2007.
One other handwritten note (dated 31 July 2006) was also prepared by Ms Wong.
Again, but for the handwritten date, there is nothing to suggest that Ms Wong had this information in August 2006.
The first time the information is reproduced by Ms Wong to any other person or party is its inclusion in her submission to Mr Sheehan (see [101] above).
I find that note also records enquiries made in 2007, not 2006.
Where, and when, then did Ms Wong get the information set out in the marginal notes?
In relation to Donut King at Target, I found that the information was obtained in 2007 (see [98] above).
In relation to QV, I find that Ms Wong obtained the information in September 2007 from Charter Keck Cramer in the following circumstances.

In August 2007, Ms Wong of Dukemaster engaged Charter Keck Cramer, valuers, to "compare the [shops in the Food Court and other parts of the Paramount Centre] with the evidence of other similar quality and generally comparable holdings for the purpose of establishing the current market rent, in accordance with the existing lease terms and conditions".
On 12 September 2007, Charter Keck Cramer provided advice by letter to Ms Wong at Dukemaster.
Part of the advice was tendered in evidence and included a chart of "Comparative Rental Evidence".
Part of that chart dealt separately with the "Food Court QV" and was in the following form: Rental Schedule --- "Food Court QV" 172-254 Lonsdale Street, Melbourne Unit No.

 As is self evident, the Rental Schedule sets out many of the details contained in the marginal notes (see [92] above).
There are some minor discrepancies --- the gross rental has in each relevant case in relation to QV been rounded down.
How, when and why that occurred is unnecessary for me to resolve.

Those discrepancies do not, however, affect or alter my finding that Ms Wong obtained the information about QV recorded in the marginal notes from this chart provided by Charter Keck Cramer in September 2007.

Finally, Ms Wong's assertion, in the witness box, that Dukemaster believed that a particular range of rents was a " range reasonable to propose at that time" (in the context of a different shop but, by analogy, applicable to each of the premises listed in the 22 August 2006 file note) is an assertion that I do not accept.
The rental range proposed to the tenants by Dukemaster in 2007 was frequently referred to by the Respondents' witnesses as the "achievable rent" for the Food Court.
The ACCC submitted that this notion of "achievable rent" seemed to focus on what was obtainable rather than what was reasonable or reflected the market value.
I agree.
The notion of "achievable rent" was discussed by Ms Wong at various times throughout her evidence.
At first, Ms Wong described this notion as "the range [she] thought the tenants would agree to".

In other words, the range of figures that were established in the August meeting between Mr Hii and Ms Wong, that eventually formed the basis for the figures proposed to the tenants, were the "range[s] that [Ms Wong] thought was achievable with those tenants" and were "achievable in the sense that [Ms Wong] thought that the tenant would agree to something within that range".

In response to a question from Counsel for the ACCC as to whether Dukemaster were hoping to achieve the highest figure within the range she had identified, she responded by saying that "[Dukemaster was] trying to achieve the best rental that [it could] achieve.
Achievable rental".

At other points in the evidence, both Mr Hii and Ms Wong appeared to contend that the notion of "achievable rental" was in some way coupled with the idea of reasonableness and was then tied, in some ill-defined fashion, to having a market value.
I reject those contentions.
There was no basis or no proper basis for Dukemaster to believe that the proposed rental figures reflected a market value and that they were reasonable.
The Respondents' description of the rents as "achievable rents" establishes no more than the tenants might (and then ultimately did) agree to pay the rent specified by Dukemaster.
The circumstances which led each of them to agree to pay the "achievable rent" specified by Dukemaster vary from tenant to tenant.
For each tenant, those circumstances which led each of them to agree to pay the "achievable rent" specified by Dukemaster is an issue which raises the operation and application of s 51AC of the TPA.

For present purposes, it is sufficient to note that the mere fact that the rents were "achievable rents" in the sense that the tenants agreed to pay them, does not of itself establish that they were reasonable, very reasonable, market value or below market value.
Conduct Induce or Capable of Inducing Error?

Again, however, a finding that the evidence reveals no basis for Dukemaster stating in January 2007 that it held a belief that the rent for Shop 3 was "very reasonable" and "below the market value" as at 3 January 2007 does not provide a sufficient basis for the further finding that each representation was conduct which was misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive.
Conduct is misleading or deceptive only if it induces or is capable of inducing error: see [10(1)] above.
In this context, Mr Sheehan's evidence was that the market rent for the annual period commencing on 1 February 2007 was $50,500 (excluding GST).
The rent charged by Dukemaster ($90,000 excluding GST) is about 80% above the market rent identified by Mr Sheehan ($50,500 excluding GST).
The form and content of Mr Sheehan's 2008 Report has been described earlier: see [71] to [83] above.
As the 2008 Report reveals, not only does the Food Court lack certain characteristics, it has a number of issues identified by Mr Sheehan as affecting the market rent (see [83] above).

In addition, in the context of Shop 3 in 2007, the figure of $90,000 (or $1,875m 2 ) 'selected' by Ms Wong, for example, was higher per m 2 per annum than the upper limit of the rents for the same period for the seven food outlets in the food court in the Telstra Building of areas between 37.6m 2 and 89.5m 2 (which ranged from $835m 2 to $1,524m 2 ) and which were within a retail amenity of some 18 shops.

Moreover, taking the so called "mid" point of a range of rents for particular premises as the Respondents sought to do to support a contention that the rents are "within range" is contrary to the evidence of Mr Sheehan that a higher rental rate per square metre generally applies to smaller outlets.

Again, in the absence of positive evidence from the Respondents that the market value of the rent for Shop 3 for the period from 1 February 2007 to 31 January 2008 of $90,000 (excluding GST) was "very reasonable" or "below the market rent" (as the 3 January 2007 letter stated), or that Ms Wong genuinely believed the market value of the rent for Shop 3 for that period was greater than $90,000 (excluding GST) (for which there was no evidence), I can only conclude that the Third and Fourth Shin Representations were misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive Mrs Shin.
The $90,000 Rent (excluding GST) was neither "very reasonable" nor "below the market value".

(C) JANUARY 2007 CONVERSATION
 Thirdly, the ACCC contends that the contents of the January 2007 conversation were misleading and deceptive because, by the January 2007 conversation, Dukemaster represented to Mrs Shin and Ms Zu that: the $90,000 Rent was very reasonable ("the Fifth Shin Representation"); it had a reasonable basis for expressing its opinion that the $90,000 Rent was very reasonable ("the Sixth Shin Representation"); the $90,000 Rent was lower than the rental paid by other [similar] tenants in the Food Court at that time ("the Seventh Shin Representation"), 
when, in fact, the $90,000 rent was not very reasonable, Dukemaster did not have a reasonable basis for expressing its opinion that the $90,000 Rent was very reasonable and further or alternatively, the $90,000 Rent was not lower than the rental paid by other tenants in the Food Court at that time.

Moreover, the ACCC submitted that Dukemaster had not obtained appropriate valuation advice or evidence in relation to the market rental for Shop 3 from 1 February 2007 to 31 January 2008 and that if it had done so, the market value was significantly less than $90,000 and was approximately $50,500 plus GST.
Fifth, Sixth and Seventh Shin Representations Conveyed?
It must be recalled that the Respondents' Counsel did not seek to cross examine Ms Zu about the contents of the January 2007 conversation: see [40] above.

The Fifth Shin Representation was conveyed by the January 2007 conversation except that the representation was that the $90,000 Rent was "reasonable" rather than "very reasonable" and the Seventh Shin Representation was also conveyed by the January 2007 conversation: see [38]-[42] above.
Was the Sixth Shin Representation conveyed?

Unlike the 27 November 2003 letter (see [28] above) and the 3 January 2007 letter (see [35] above), Ms Wong did not state that she believed the $90,000 Rent was very reasonable and below the market rent: see [38] --- [42] above.
However, that is not the end of the enquiry.
As stated in the summary of principles set out above (see [10]), there will be circumstances where an opinion may convey there is a basis for it and that it is honestly held.
Moreover, it is wrong to select particular words and acts in isolation without viewing them in context.
In my view, the Sixth Shin Representation was conveyed.
It was conveyed by the express words of the January 2007 conversation.

A conclusion which is fortified by (although not dependent upon) the context in which it was made - the fact and contents of each the 27 November 2003 letter (see [28] above), the 3 January 2007 letter (see [35] above) and the Fifth and Seventh Shin Representations.

Fifth, Sixth and Seventh Shin Representations Misleading or Deceptive or Likely to Mislead or Deceive
 Taken as a whole, the evidence reveals no basis for Dukemaster holding a belief that the rent for Shop 3 was "reasonable", "very reasonable" and "lower than the rental paid by other tenants in the Food Court at that time".
That conclusion applies with equal force in relation to the Sixth Shin Representation.

Dukemaster had not obtained valuation advice or evidence in relation to the market rental for Shop 3 for the period from 1 February 2007 to 31 January 2008 that provided a basis for it holding a belief that the rental it was seeking for Shop 3 was "reasonable", "very reasonable" and "lower than the rental paid by other tenants in the Food Court at that time".
Conduct Induce or Capable of Inducing Error?

Does such a finding however provide a sufficient basis for the further finding that each representation was conduct which was misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive: see [10(1)] above?
For the reasons set out above at [88] to [111], the conduct comprising the Fifth and Sixth Shin Representations was misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive.

In the absence of positive evidence from the Respondents that the market value of the rent for Shop 3 for the period from 1 February 2007 to 31 January 2008 of $90,000 (excluding GST) was "reasonable", I can only conclude that the Fifth and Sixth Shin Representations were misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive Mrs Shin.
The $90,000 Rent (excluding GST) was not "reasonable".
The Seventh Shin Representation requires separate consideration.
Was the representation that "the $90,000 rent was lower than the rental paid by other [similar] tenants in the Food Court at that time" misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive?
The Respondents did not seek to identify who were the "other [similar] tenants in the Food Court at that time".
Annexure B (prepared by the Respondents) indicates that as at 30 June 2007, the rate per m 2 varied not only between shops of different areas but between shops of the same or similar area.
For example, Shops 3 and 4 were of similar size and the rate per m 2 sought by Dukemaster was the same - $1,875.00 per m 2 .
Shops 8 and 11 were of similar size but smaller than Shops 3 and 4 and the rate per m 2 sought by Dukemaster varied between $2,385 per m 2 and $1,615 per m 2 .

Again, in the absence of positive evidence from the Respondents that "the $90,000 rent was lower than the rental paid by other [similar] tenants in the Food Court at that time", I can only conclude that the Seventh Shin Representation was misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive Mrs Shin.

Moreover, for the reasons earlier identified, in contravention of s 53(e) of the TPA, by the Seventh Shin Representation, Dukemaster made a false or misleading representation with respect to the price of goods or services.
(3) UNCONSCIONABLE CONDUCT?
The ACCC also alleged that Dukemaster's conduct was unconscionable within the meaning of s 51AC(1)(a) of the TPA.
A summary of the relevant legal principles is set out in Section B above.

Given my earlier findings in relation to s 52 of the TPA, and subject to the question of the appropriateness of any declarations and injunctions, a contravention of s 51AC would not otherwise add to or alter the other relief available: see generally Part VI of the TPA.

(6) Dukemaster not obtaining appropriate valuation advice or evidence in relation to the market rent for Shop 3 for the period from 1 February 2004 to 31 January 2005 and particularly before making the First and Second Shin representations.
As is self evident, the list of factors is long.
There was much dispute between the parties whether or not the ACCC had formally proved the matters alleged.
I do not consider that it is necessary for the Court to seek to resolve whether or not the ACCC should and if so, has, formally proved each fact or matter.
That is not what s 51AC requires.
In the end, Dukemaster supplied goods or services (in the form of lease premises) to a business consumer, Mrs Shin.
The question is whether that supply was, in all the circumstances, unconscionable.
In assessing that question, s 51AC(3) identifies some matters to which the Court may, but need not have regard.
In the present case, the ACCC contends that the matters listed in s 51AC(3)(a), (c), (d), (j) and (k) are relevant.
In all the circumstances, I consider that Dukemaster's conduct in relation to the renewal of the First Shop 3 Lease and the "negotiation" of the Second Shop 3 Lease was unconscionable.

The First and Second Shin Representations were conveyed in a letter from Dukemaster to Mrs Shin and were not only misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive Mrs Shin (see Section C(2)(a) above) but: were conveyed to Mrs Shin who Dukemaster knew had little or no ability to speak or read English; were intended by Dukemaster to secure a renewal of the lease at a rental for which there was no basis beyond Dukemaster's decision to seek the amount stated; required a response within a period of 11 days when there was no explanation provided by Dukemaster to justify the limited time in which Mrs Shin could respond.
(The Respondents contended that Mrs Shin should have taken steps to enquire about the market rent for the shop prior to being told by Dukemaster of the amount of increased rent.
I reject that contention.
Why would she?
She had spent considerable time and capital in buying the business (with all of the fixtures and fittings), trading the business to seek to develop it and had no intention or need to shift premises.
It is not surprising that a person in her position would not take steps to enquire about the market rent for the shop prior to being told by Dukemaster what rent it intended to seek from her).
Dukemaster's conduct was irreconcilable with what was right or reasonable.

If that was not enough, in February 2004 Dukemaster delivered lease documents to Mrs Shin that, contrary to the 27 November 2003 letter, were not a renewal of lease but a new and different lease where the terms of the new lease were different in critical respects: see [31] above.
In the covering letter, Dukemaster failed to draw any of these issues to the attention of Mrs Shin.
That conduct, in the context of the earlier conduct (see [128] above) was clearly unfair and unreasonable and contravened s 51AC of the TPA.
Again, in all the circumstances, I consider that Dukemaster's conduct in relation to the Third Shop 3 Lease was unconscionable.

The Third to Seventh Shin Representations were conveyed and were not only misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive Mrs Shin (see Sections C(2)(b) and (c) above) but: were conveyed to Mrs Shin who Dukemaster knew had little or no ability to speak or read English; were intended by Dukemaster to secure a renewal of the lease at a rental for which there was no basis beyond Dukemaster's decision to seek the amount stated; required a response within a period of 7 days, at a time when independent advice was not readily available and when there was no explanation provided by Dukemaster to justify the limited time in which Mrs Shin could respond.
Dukemaster's conduct was irreconcilable with what is right or reasonable.

The Respondents contended that what transpired after receipt of the 3 January 2007 letter was "in fact a process of negotiation which was undertaken by and on behalf of Mrs Shin", negotiations which Mrs Shin "decided to conclude on 9 January 2007 by signing the renewal letter".
I reject the Respondents' description of what transpired after receipt of the 3 January 2007 letter.

On no view, was there a "negotiation" or for that matter a "negotiation" which Mrs Shin "decided to conclude": see Insight Oceania Pty Ltd v Philips Electronics Australia Ltd [2008] NSWSC 710 at [166] ; Strickland v Minister for Lands for Western Australia (1998) 85 FCR 319; Black's Law Dictionary (4th ed, Thomson Reuters, 2004) "Negotiation".
A rent was established.
At no point was it indicated that it would be reduced.

Although an additional term was granted, it was never in any way established that Mrs Wong sought this additional term as some sort of trade-off --- in fact, the evidence established that Mrs Shin simply had no choice but to accept the $90,000 Rent per annum.
It was not a negotiation --- it was an ultimatum.

(C) DUKEMASTER'S CONDUCT IN MARCH 2007
 Finally, with respect to the conduct of Dukemaster that occurred after the entry into the Third Shop 3 Lease, particularly after receipt of the 19 March 2007 letter from Jholl Lawyers & Consultants (see [49] above), the ACCC contends that the circumstances said to give rise to a finding of unconscionability were that: 
Dukemaster's conduct in relation to the continuing operation of the Third Shop 3 Lease was, in all the circumstances, unconscionable because Dukemaster refused to properly address Mrs Shin's complaint about the rent payable under the Third Shop 3 Lease particularly given Dukemaster's conduct in [130(1)-(10)] above.
The Respondents contended that the rent was duly considered and addressed as an aspect of the negotiations referred to in [132] above.
As I have already explained, that requires an assumption which cannot be justified.

Although Mrs Shin obviously had access to legal advice at the time of this March 2007 conduct, I consider Dukemaster's conduct was unconscionable because Dukemaster: refused to address Mrs Shin's complaint regarding the excessive rent for the Third Shop 3 Lease, including rejecting a proposal to proceed to rental determination, when that rent had no basis beyond Dukemaster's decision to seek the amount stated; denied that Mrs Shin had ever objected to the rental for the Third Shop 3 Lease, which clearly was not accurate; and threatened to evict Mrs Shin should she not pay the balance of the March rent at the new rate within 7 days.
This conduct is not reconcilable with what is right or reasonable.
Dukemaster persisted in following a course of conduct that deliberately attempted to deny Mrs Shin any opportunity to challenge the proposed rent.
Before leaving this issue of unconscionability, it is necessary to address a number of other contentions of the Respondents concerning the ACCC's claim under s 51AC of the TPA.

Broadly, they can be divided into two groups: (a) resources to which the tenant (in this case, Mrs Shin) could have regard that would mitigate against a finding of unconscionable conduct and (b) common aspects of the commercial leasing industry that were present in this case and would tend against a finding of unconscionable conduct.
It appeared that many of these factors were directed at establishing parity of bargaining positions, being a consideration relevant to s 51AC(3)(a).
Although I acknowledge that this was one of the pleaded matters to which I could have regard, ultimately I am bound to determine whether the conduct was, "in all the circumstances, unconscionable".

In all the circumstances I find that the actions of Dukemaster were deliberate (or at least reckless), showed no regard for conscience and were irreconcilable with what is right or reasonable: see discussion of relevant principles at [17] above.
Nevertheless, for the sake of completeness, I will address the various matters raised by the Respondents in their many submissions.
First, the Respondents' submissions about the resources available to Mrs Shin in conducting the Korean Lunch Box business.

The Respondents submitted that Mrs Shin, (1) through Ms Zu, had access to a well-educated translator, (2) could readily gain access to legal advice, (3) could seek assistance from other tenants when required, (4) had the advantage of the Tenants' Committee and (5) was a well-experienced business woman.
The significance and substance of (1) is dubious.

Ms Zu did an admirable job assisting her mother, but there was nothing in the sworn or viva voce evidence to suggest that the assistance she provided as a 22 year old undergraduate significantly improved her mother's business decisions or her ability to address the serious issues raised by Dukemaster in the limited time provided by Dukemaster.

In relation to (2), although it was, in a vague sense, established that Mrs Shin had used legal assistance in the past, the fact remains that the conduct of the Respondents required decisions to be made in such a limited period of time that legal advice would have been difficult to obtain, in circumstances where it seems clear that the Respondents would have maintained their position and undertaken their conduct in any case.
The relevance of (3) and (4) is also problematic.
No evidence was adduced to demonstrate any benefit was provided to Mrs Shin by (3) or (4) when interacting with Dukemaster that would alter my finding that Dukemaster's conduct was unconscionable.
Finally, (5) is an interesting point.
It is true that Mrs Shin had the better part of a decade's worth of experience in the take-away food industry.

However, the evidence established that Mrs Shin had only a limited grasp of the various business documents supplied to her and, at the very least, did not have any grasp of the commercial and legal circumstances beyond the limited aspects I have outlined above.

The Respondents' second broad series of submissions was that there were a number of endemic aspects of the commercial leasing industry that were the subject of complaint in this matter that should not be found to be aspects of unconscionable conduct.
In other words, by finding that Dukemaster's conduct was unconscionable, I risked damning large segments of the industry.

These matters were that (1) there were other conditions in the lease and that it would be wrong to focus only on the rent payable, (2) the fact that the tenants' businesses were or were not operating at a profit should not be a relevant consideration in negotiating with those tenants, (3) the market was flexible --- there were other locations and the goodwill or reputation of their tenants was at least to some extent transferable, (4) the relevant lease documents were straightforward and easily understood and (5) Mrs Shin (and the other tenants) were advised of the right to go to rental determination.
Many aspects of the Respondents' submission on this second category may be accepted.
With respect to (1), it is obvious, perhaps so much so that it becomes trite to say that there will be many reasons a tenant ultimately agrees to a lease.
Rent will be one factor, but there may be others.

However, in this case, I was taken to and I cannot find any other provision of the relevant lease documents that would dissuade me from finding that in all the circumstances Dukemaster's conduct was unconscionable.

With respect to (2) --- I agree that in the absence of direct evidence about profitability having been raised by a tenant with a landlord as a reason for seeking a particular outcome whether directly, by a lease term requiring a tenant to disclose profitability to a landlord on a regular basis or some other basis, it would be inappropriate to require a landlord to enquire of the financial state of parties with which they are negotiating in an arm's length transaction lest they be found to be behaving unconscionably.
The situation with respect to the matters listed in (3)-(5) above is less clear.
Mr Sheehan's evidence does not support (3): see for example [82] and [83] above.

Even in the absence of that evidence, it is undeniable that a tenant relying upon foot trade and repeat custom would prefer to stay in a location where it has already invested time and money to establish a presence.

In relation to (4), determining the legal consequences of the many and various lease documents and the correspondence relating to them was and remains a difficult task for someone trained in the law, let alone someone who speaks and reads English poorly with no legal training.

Finally, the fact that Mrs Shin was advised of her right to go to rental determination in the 27 November 2003 and 3 January 2007 letters largely ignores the subject matter of this entire dispute --- the fact is that it was not shown that Mrs Shin understood other than in the most general nature what this meant, and moreover, the conduct of the Respondents in the period surrounding these letters largely destroyed any comfort such advice would have provided.

(4) RELIEF 
 In relation to these contraventions of the TPA, it is appropriate that there be declarations and injunctions.
In addition, pursuant to s 87(1A) (read with s 87(1AA)) of the TPA, the Respondents should refund to Mrs Shin the amount of rent she was overcharged totalling $55,082.

The sum of $55,082 is calculated by subtracting the market rent from the rent in fact paid by Mrs Shin as follows: 
01/01/04 --- 31/01/07 $15,144
 
02/02/07 --- 31/01/08 $39,938
 
 That leaves the question of interest.
The ACCC sought interest on two bases.
First, under s 51A of the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 (Cth) ("the FCA"), the ACCC sought interest on the amounts overpaid from the date of overpayment.
It selected an interest rate of 9%.
The Respondents did not seek to challenge the entitlement to interest or the rate.
In my view, Mrs Shin was entitled to interest on those amounts from the date of payment.
That amount of interest for the period up to and including 28 February 2009 is $10,679.
The ACCC also sought interest on the total amount ($65,761) from 1 March 2009.
The date reflects the fact that the ACCC's calculation of interest on the overpayments was up to and including 28 February 2009.
The form of the order sought by the ACCC is not appropriate.
It seeks interest on interest.
Instead, the Respondents should pay Mrs Shin interest on the amounts overpaid (see [141] above) from and including 1 March 2009.
If the parties are unable to quantify that amount, they may have the matter re-listed.

D. SHOP 4 --- EAST ON PARAMOUNT
(1) FACTS 
 (A) EARLY APRIL 2004 INCLUDING 16 MARCH 2004 LETTER AND 16 MARCH 2004 CONVERSATION
 East on Paramount, a Chinese take away business, located in Shop 4 in the Food Court is operated by a married couple --- Mrs Lai and Mr Tan.
Mrs Lai did not give viva voce evidence and was not cross examined.
All but one paragraph of her affidavit evidence was tendered without objection.
That affidavit disclosed that Mrs Lai was born in East Timor and speaks Hakka and that her English, Cantonese and Mandarin are limited.

The balance of her affidavit describes the difficulties she and her husband have had paying the rent for Shop 4 and that any complaints by them to Mr Sant about the poor business and the rent were met with a response along the lines that they "had to take [their] complaints upstairs".
Mr Tan was born in Malaysia and came to Australia in 1982.
He speaks fluent Cantonese, Mandarin, Hakka and a little English.
Since his arrival in Australia, Mr Tan has worked as a cook.
Mr Tan provided both affidavit and oral evidence.
He was cross examined.
He gave evidence with the assistance of a Cantonese interpreter.
In 1998, Mr Tan worked part time as a cook for the previous owners of East on Paramount - Dukemaster.
On his first day, Mr Tan met Ms Wong.
In early 1999, Ms Wong told Mr Tan that Dukemaster were selling East on Paramount and asked him if he was interested in buying the business.

Mr Tan discussed the idea with his wife and after negotiations with Ms Wong and Mr Peter Cook (then the Centre Manager), Mr Tan and his wife agreed to purchase the business for $47,500 on the basis of a five year lease with two options to renew for three years.
The initial rent was $55,000 per annum with the first two months rent free and rent increases of 3% each year.
The lease was signed on 4 May 1999.
It commenced on 12 April 1999 ("the First Shop 4 Lease").
It was not a standard lease.
To the extent that the leasing history was not in dispute, it is summarised in Annexure A.
The first year of trading went well.
By the second year, takings had fallen.
Customer numbers had reduced and there was less advertising or promotion of the Paramount Centre by Dukemaster.

At some time during the first term, East on Paramount ceased weekend trading because there was insufficient traffic in the Food Court to justify the costs incurred in opening for trade on the weekends.

Mr Tan also gave sworn evidence, not the subject of cross examination by the Respondents' Counsel, that during the first term he complained to Ms Wong and Mr Sant about the rent being too high and the lack of customers coming to the Food Court.
Sometime in early March 2004, Mr Tan telephoned Ms Wong and told her that they wanted to renew the lease that was due to expire in April of that year.
Ms Wong responded saying that it would be okay to renew the lease.
At that time, she did not say anything about the rent.

On 16 March 2004, Ms Wong came to Shop 4 and gave Mr Tan a letter from Dukemaster in the following terms ("the 16 March 2004 letter"): 
We note the lease for the above shop will expire on 11/04/2004.
Please advise by 5:00pm 23/03/2004 whether you will exercise the option for a further term of 3 years.
Should you wish to exercise the option for a further term, we advise the rent for the above shop will be $72,000.00pa plus GST commencing 12/04/2004.
We believe the new rent is very reasonable and below the market value.
If you object to our proposed rent, the matter will proceed to valuation in accordance with clause RC3.2 of the lease contract .

...
 
 
(Emphasis added).
When Ms Wong gave Mr Tan the 16 March 2004 letter, Mr Tan told her that the rental was "very expensive" and that if he accepted the $72,000 rent, he did not think he could continue with his business.
Ms Wong replied saying that she had got a "specialist" for this rental determination, that the amount was $80,000 and the $72,000 rent was already discounted.
Mr Tan said that he did not think he had the ability to run his business because the rent was so expensive.

Ms Wong replied saying that the rent determination was correct and that Mr Tan could get another person to do the rental determination (at a cost to him of $4,000), but the rental determination would be $80,000 and she would not then give Mr Tan any discount.
Mr Tan was cross examined about the conversation ("the 16 March 2004 conversation").
During his cross examination, Mr Tan restated his evidence in chief.

He also stated that he understood the last sentence of the 16 March 2004 letter entitled him to proceed to an independent valuation but that he did not adopt that course because of the statements made to him by Ms Wong that: she had got a "specialist" for the rental determination; the amount of that determination was $80,000; the $72,000 rent was already a discount; and although Mr Tan could get another person to do the rental determination, the rental determination would be $80,000 and she would not then give Mr Tan any discount and he would have to pay $4,000 for the rental determination fee (according to Ms Wong, this would be half of the total fee, the other half to be paid by Dukemaster).
Ms Wong's denial of the contents of the 16 March 2004 conversation was not put to Mr Tan.
During examination-in-chief, Ms Wong gave evidence that she told Mr Tan that Dukemaster had checked and done comparisons.
As noted earlier, that statement was false: see [66] to [68] above.

Moreover, the statement is contradicted by the rents Dukemaster asked of the other tenants - the Korean Lunch Box rent was $48,000 plus GST (which was exactly the same size as Shop 4) and the rent for Boxcar café (just under twice the size of Shop 4) was $72,000 plus GST: see Annexure A.
Mr Tan discussed the rent increase with his wife.
They decided that the $72,000 rent was too expensive and they would approach Ms Wong again.
At that time, Mr Tan did not sign the 16 March 2004 letter.
Mr Tan's evidence was that subsequently he telephoned Ms Wong and spoke to her in Cantonese and told her that he would like to see her manager.
Mr Tan's evidence was that Ms Wong told him the manager was overseas in Malaysia and was very busy and had "no time to see [him]" and "there's no negotiation over the rental".
Ms Wong's evidence was that she did not recall this conversation and she denied telling Mr Tan that her manager was overseas and too busy to talk to him.
Significantly, Ms Wong's denial of the contents of the conversation was not put to Mr Tan by the Respondents' Counsel.
On balance, I accept Mr Tan's evidence that he spoke to Ms Wong in the terms he stated.
There is a hand written annotation on the 16 March 2004 letter which reads "Tenant notified re acceptance of proposed rent on 31/3/04".
This appears to be consistent with the evidence of Ms Wong who recalled that Mr Tan orally assented to the proposed rent sometime in late March.

(B) APRIL 2004 --- 2007 INCLUDING 5 MARCH 2007 LETTER AND 5 MARCH 2007 CONVERSATION
 On 5 April 2004, Mr Tan and Mrs Lai received a letter from Dukemaster's lawyers enclosing a copy of a draft lease for Shop 4.
The lease was for three years with one further term of three years.
The rent was $72,000 plus GST for the first year, $74,160 plus GST for the second year and $76,384.80 plus GST for the third year.

The 5 April 2004 letter stated: 
We enclose:
 
 Lease, in duplicate for your perusal and execution.
We have forwarded the Lease to you subject to approval by the Lessor of all terms and conditions contained in the Lease.
Retail Leases information brochure.
We look forward to the return of all Lease documents together with a copy of the Disclosure Statement previously handed to you by the Lessor.
If you have a solicitor acting for you in this matter we suggest that you take the enclosed documents to your solicitor as soon as possible.

If you execute and return the Lease to us without advice from a solicitor our client will treat your execution and return of the Lease as acknowledgement by you that you are satisfied with all the terms and conditions in the Lease.
The enclosed lease documents were standard.
Mr Tan delayed signing the documents because he was worried about the high rent.
The lease commenced on 12 April 2004.
It was not until about 17 May 2004 that Mr Tan and Mrs Lai signed the documents.

Mr Tan's evidence was that although the business was not good in 2004, he still signed the lease because he and his wife had put a lot of money and effort into the shop and did not want to risk losing the business ("the Second Shop 4 Lease").
Sometime in December 2006, Mr Tan told Ms Wong that he and his wife wished to renew the lease for a further term.
Ms Wong told Mr Tan that they were able to do so.
Nothing further transpired until 5 March 2007 when Ms Wong came to the shop and handed Mr Tan a letter ("the 5 March 2007 letter").

That letter stated: 
Thank you for your exercise of option for further term of 3 years in relation to the above lease.

We note the current lease expires on 11 th April 2007 and we advise the following:
 
 
Commencement Date: 12 th April 2007
 
Rent per annum: 1 st year $90000.00 (plus GST)
 
 2 nd year $92700.00 (plus GST)
 
 3 rd year $95481.00 (plus GST)
 
 
Please advise by 5.00pm on 9 th March 2007 whether you accept this offer.
We believe that the new rent is very reasonable and below the market value.
If you object to our proposed rent, the matter will proceed to valuation in accordance with clause 5-16(A) of the lease contract.
If the above proposals are acceptable to you please advise us by signing below and return a copy to us by 5pm on 9 th March 2007.
We will instruct our solicitors to prepare the lease and forward it to you for your perusal and execution.
If you have any queries in relation to this matter, please contact this office.

Yours sincerely,
 
 
 PATRICIA WONG 
 
 GENERAL MANAGER 
 
 
(Emphasis added).

The form and content of this letter (subject to different particulars) was the same as the letter Dukemaster sent to the Korean Lunch Box on 3 January 2007 (see [35] above) and to Gomax in relation to Boxcar Café on 3 January 2007 (see [247] below).
Ms Wong told Mr Tan that the rent would now be $90,000 per annum.

In response to Mr Tan saying that it was too expensive, Ms Wong said that it was the correct amount and that the rental in "the Centre in the future would be $90,000" ("the 5 March 2007 conversation").
Ms Wong's evidence was that she told Mr Tan that the rent was reasonable and nothing more.
Despite being cross examined about the contents of this conversation, Mr Tan steadfastly maintained his position that Ms Wong had referred to "the Centre".
Moreover, the substance of the allegations is consistent with other statements Ms Wong made to other tenants which were not the subject of direct challenge.
Mr Tan showed the 5 March 2007 letter to Mr Vasta, another shop owner in the Food Court.
Mr Vasta pointed out to Mr Tan that the 5 March 2007 letter required a response by 9 March, just four days away.
Mr Vasta told Mr Tan that that was not enough time for him to consider the 5 March 2007 letter, that he should not sign it and that Mr Tan should get his own market valuation under the lease.
Mr Tan then spoke with two other tenants in the Food Court and they told him that Dukemaster had also put their rent up a lot.
The three tenants (Mr Tan, Irene Watts from "Chine on Paramount" and Mr Ho from "Boxcar Café") agreed to use the same rent valuer and to share the cost.
On 22 March 2007, a further letter was delivered to Mr Tan.

This letter was from Dukemaster's lawyers and was in part in the following terms: 
We act for the above-named Landlord.
We are instructed that you have exercised your option for a further term of three (3) years starting on 12 April 2007.

We now enclose herewith the following:-
 
 Disclosure Statement in duplicate for your attention ; and
 
Please sign both copies of the Disclosure Statement where indicated and return one (1) copy to our office.
Retail Leases information brochure for your retention.
We will prepare the lease and forward to you or your Solicitor when the first year rent for the Renewed Lease is agreed to by you and our client.
Our client in a letter to you of the 5 March 2007 has proposed the rent of $90,000 per annum plus GST for the first year of the Renewed Lease.
Our client is of the opinion that the rent of $90,000 per annum plus GST is the market rent for the premises.
We are instructed that you have so far not agreed to the rent proposed by our client.
Under Clause 5.16A of the Lease, if both parties cannot agree on the rent, then the rent is to be to be determined by a Valuer appointed by the President of the Australian Institute of Valuers.
Our client requires your response to our client's proposed rent of $90,000 per annum plus GST by the 26 March 2007 .
If we do not have your response by the 26 March 2007, our client proposes that the rent be determined by a Valuer.

... 
 
(Emphasis added).
The letter did not contain any reference to the options to renew.
Mr Tan showed the letter to Mr Vasta.
Again, the letter re quired a response within four days.

The next day, 23 March 2007, Mr Tan sent a letter to Dukemaster which stated: 
This letter is to advise that the rental charges per annum offered for the three (3) years lease term commencing 12 April 2007 to Ricky Tan & Deolinda Lai is NOT accepted.
(Emphasis in original).
There was some inconsistency about the source of the contents of this letter.
Mr Tan's sworn evidence was that he copied the letter from a letter that Irene from "Chine on Paramount" had sent to Dukemaster.
Mr Vasta's evidence was that he typed the letter for Mr Tan.
In the end, it is sufficient to note that the letter was not drafted by Mr Tan but drafted for him by another tenant in the Food Court.
Ultimately, Mr Sheehan was appointed by the Small Business Commissioner to prepare a rental valuation for shops in the Food Court including Mr Tan and Mrs Lai's shop, Shop 4.
The cost of the rental determination was shared between Dukemaster, Mr Tan, Mr Ho and Irene from "Chine on Paramount".
Mr Tan, Mr Ho and Irene from "Chine on Paramount" also engaged a valuer, Simpson Forsyth, to prepare a submission to Mr Sheehan.
They also shared the cost of the preparation of the submission.
At 2:35 pm on 17 April 2007, Dukemaster's lawyers hand delivered a letter of demand to Mr Tan and Mrs Lai at the shop.

The letter stated: 
We are instructed that you are in default under the Lease as you have failed to pay the monthly rent of $7,001.91 (inclusive of GST) due on the 1 April 2007.
We are further instructed that no arrangements have been made by you with the Landlord to pay the outstanding amount despite request to you by our client for payment.
Please note that the April rent is based on the final year's rent of the expired Lease until you and our client come to an agreement on the rent for the first year of the Renewed Lease.

Notice is hereby given that unless outstanding amount totalling $7,001.91 is paid by 3.30pm on or before Tuesday, 24 April 2007, our client will re-enter and take possession of the premises without any further notice to you.

In the event that our client re-enter (sic), and take possession of the premises, we have instructions to issue legal proceedings against you to recover all damages suffered by our client as a result of your defaulting on the Lease.
We advise that the Landlord is also entitled to charge interests (sic) on the overdue moneys.
Our client reserves all its rights under the Lease.
A copy of the letter was sent to Dukemaster.
Mr Tan showed the letter to Mr Vasta who explained the contents to Mr Tan.
Mr Vasta told Mr Tan that if he and his wife did not pay the rent by 24 April 2007, Dukemaster would take possession of the shop.
Mr Tan was upset about receiving this letter.
It was the first time that he and his wife had received a letter of demand from Dukemaster about paying the rent late.
On one previous occasion, Ms Wong had telephoned Mr Tan and suggested that he pay the outstanding rent in two instalments.
On another previous occasion in relation to the rent for March 2007, Mr Tan did not pay the rent until 28 March but did not receive any demand or threat.
Instead, Mr Sant turned up at the shop week after week to ask if they could pay the rent.
On 24 April 2007, Mr Tan paid $7,001.91 in arrears of rent to Dukemaster.
In early June 2007, Mr Vasta told Mr Tan that Mr Sant and another man had gone into Mr Tan's shop early in the morning before Mr Tan had arrived and were taking measurements.
Mr Tan rang Ms Wong straight away.
He spoke to Ms Wong in English.
Mr Vasta was standing next to Mr Tan.
Ms Wong told Mr Tan that she was entitled to have the measurements taken.
Mr Tan asked her about the rent and said it was too high.
Ms Wong offered to reduce the rent for the new lease by $6,000 per year and offered Mr Tan a three by three lease, a total of six years.
Mr Tan responded by saying that he was in a hurry.
Mr Tan was not cross-examined about the fact or contents of this conversation and Ms Wong did not deal with this conversation either in her affidavits or in her oral evidence.
Mr Tan did not consider the rent reduction significant.
Mr Tan discussed the offer with his wife and they decided not to accept Ms Wong's offer of the rent reduction as they still considered the rent was too high for the shop.
Mr Tan and his wife decided to take their chances on the getting a lower rent valuation from the independent valuer.

On about 26 July 2007, Mr Tan received a copy of Mr Sheehan's rental determination --- he determined that the rental for Shop 4 should be lowered to $40,500 per annum plus GST for the period from 12 April 2007 until 11 April 2008.
On 22 October 2007, Mr Tan and his wife signed the new lease with Dukemaster.
The new rent was $40,500 per annum plus GST with a 3% increase each year ("the Third Shop 4 Lease").
Ms Wong refused Mr Tan a further term on the lease.
Mr Tan's evidence was that Ms Wong said that she knew he wanted to sell.
Mr Tan was not cross examined about the fact or contents of this conversation.
Ms Wong did not deal with this conversation either in her affidavits or in her oral evidence.
No further lease term was granted by Dukemaster.
The current lease expires on 11 April 2010.
(2) CONDUCT MISLEADING OR DECEPTIVE OR LIKELY TO MISLEAD OR DECEIVE?
The ACCC had four complaints.
Each complaint dealt with separate representations.
Although some of the representations contain common elements, each must be considered separately because each is said to constitute a separate contravention of s 52 of the TPA.

(A) 16 MARCH 2004 LETTER
 First, the ACCC contended that the contents of the 16 March 2004 letter (see [151] above) were misleading and deceptive because, by the 16 March 2004 letter, Dukemaster represented to Mr Tan and Mrs Lai that: it believed that the proposed rent for the renewal of Shop 4 of $72,000 plus GST from 12 April 2004 to 11 April 2005 ("the $72,000 Rent") was very reasonable and below the market value ("the First Tan and Lai Representation"); it had a reasonable basis for believing that the $72,000 Rent was very reasonable and below the market value ("the Second Tan and Lai Representation"), 
when, in fact, Dukemaster did not believe and did not have a reasonable basis for believing that the $72,000 Rent was very reasonable and below the market value.

Moreover, the ACCC submitted that Dukemaster had not obtained appropriate valuation advice or evidence in relation to the market rental for Shop 4 from 12 April 2004 to 11 April 2005 and that if it had done so, the market value was approximately $43,000 plus GST.
As with Shop 3 (see [61]), two questions arise in the context of s 52 of the TPA.
(1) Was each representation conveyed and (2) if yes to (1), was it misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive?
Representations Conveyed?
In its terms, the 16 March 2004 letter made the First and Second Tan and Lai Representations: see [151] above.
From Mr Tan and Mrs Lai's perspective, it is apparent that Dukemaster and Ms Wong (as Dukemaster's representative) knew what other tenants in the Food Court in the Paramount Centre were paying.

Mr Tan and Mrs Lai did not know what other tenants were paying and they were not in a position to know whether or not Dukemaster had sought valuation advice or information about comparable rents and they were not in a position to obtain information about comparable rents.
That was a process which they neither had the means or ability to undertake.
Representations Misleading or Deceptive or Likely to Mislead or Deceive?

The ACCC's complaint concerns the representations that the $72,000 Rent was "very reasonable" and "below the market value" and that Dukemaster had a reasonable basis for believing that the $72,000 Rent was very reasonable and below the market value.
Those issues are interlinked.

As with Shop 3 (see [66] above), Ms Wong did not explain, except in the most general terms, how the figure of $72,000 plus GST for Shop 4 referred to in the 16 March 2004 letter was selected as the rent to be sought for Shop 4.

At its highest, her evidence was that the figure was based on what she knew "about the rents being paid by tenants in the area surrounding the ... Paramount Centre" and "on the rents paid by other tenants in the [F]ood [C]ourt of the ... Paramount Centre".
Moreover, contrary to Ms Wong's affidavit, the statement in the letter was not that the rent was "reasonable" but that it was "very reasonable".
Ms Wong's explanation why, in this case, she fixed upon a rental of $72,000, should not be accepted for the same reasons as I rejected her explanation in relation to Shop 3 (see [66] --- [68] above).

Taken as a whole (see also [66] --- [68] above), the evidence reveals no basis for Ms Wong or Dukemaster stating in 16 March 2004 letter that it held a belief that the rent for Shop 4 was "very reasonable" and "below the market value".

Dukemaster had not obtained valuation advice or evidence in relation to the market rental for Shop 4 for the period 12 April 2004 to 11 April 2005 that provided a basis for it holding a belief that the rental it was seeking for Shop 4 was "very reasonable" and "below the market value".
Conduct Induce or Capable of Inducing Error?

As explained earlier (see [10(1)] above), if the evidence shows that the opinion expressed by Dukemaster lacked any or any adequate basis, the conduct contravenes s 52 of the TPA only if that conduct induces or is capable of inducing error.

If the rent referred to in the 16 March 2004 letter was in fact "very reasonable" and / or "below the market value", then it would not be shown that the conduct complained of by the ACCC could induce or would be capable of inducing error.

In relation to Shop 4, I consider that the conduct complained of is misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive because it is much more probable than not that the $72,000 Rent was not "very reasonable" and it was not "below the market value".
I have earlier analysed the market rent evidence: see [71] to [85] above.
In relation to Shop 4, Mr Sheehan was asked to express an opinion on the current market rent of Shop 4 for the annual period commencing on 12 April 2004.

Against the background set out in that earlier analysis (see [71] to [85] above) in dealing with Shop 4, Mr Sheehan noted that the previous rent for the shop for the period from 12 April 2003 to 11 April 2004 was $61,902.98 per annum.

Shop 4 he described as "situated within the [w]estern section of the Little Bourke Street level" and, "[i]n comparison to other food service outlets within the [F]ood [C]ourt ...[had] a fairly average frontage for the Food Court of about 7.5m".

As the summary of his evidence records (see Annexure C), Mr Sheehan expressed the view that the market rent for Shop 4 for the annual period from 12 April 2004 was $43,000 (excluding GST), not $72,000 (excluding GST).
The rent charged by Dukemaster ($72,000 excluding GST) is more than 66% above the market rent identified by Mr Sheehan ($43,000 excluding GST).

In the absence of positive evidence from the Respondents that the market value of the rent for Shop 4 for the period 12 April 2004 to 11 April 2005 of $72,000 (excluding GST) was "very reasonable" or "below the market value" (as the 16 March 2004 letter stated it to be), or that Ms Wong genuinely believed the market value of the rent for Shop 4 for that period was greater than $72,000 (excluding GST), I can only conclude that the First and Second Tan and Lai Representations were misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive Mr Tan and Mrs Lai.
The $72,000 Rent (excluding GST) was neither "very reasonable" nor "below the market value".

(B) 16 MARCH 2004 CONVERSATION 
 Secondly, the ACCC contends that the contents of the 16 March 2004 conversation (see [152] --- [154] above) were misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive because, by that conversation, Dukemaster represented to Mr Tan that: it had obtained a specialist to determine the market rental for Shop 4 and that specialist had determined that the market rental for Shop 4 was $80,000 per annum ("the Third Tan and Lai Representation"); and the $72,000 Rent was a discount on the market rental of $80,000 per annum for Shop 4 ("the Fourth Tan and Lai Representation"), 
when, in fact, Dukemaster had not, at the relevant time, asked a specialist to determine the market rental for Shop 4 from 12 April 2004 to 11 April 2005 and the $72,000 Rent was not a discount on the market rental for Shop 4 at that time and that if it had done so, the market value was significantly less than $72,000 and was approximately $43,000 GST.
Again, the two questions arise in the context of s 52 of the TPA.
(1) Was each representation conveyed and (2) if yes to (1), was it misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive?
Representations Conveyed?
Despite vigorous cross examination, Mr Tan's account of the 16 March 2004 conversation was not shaken.
Moreover, Ms Wong's denial of the conversation was not put to Mr Tan.
The Third and Fourth Tan and Lai Representations were conveyed by the 16 March 2004 conversation: see [152] to [154] above.
Representations Misleading or Deceptive or Likely to Mislead or Deceive?
The evidence reveals no basis for Dukemaster making the Third Tan and Lai Representation.

Dukemaster did not lead any evidence that it had retained a "specialist", that it had retained a "specialist" to determine the market rental for Shop 4, that any such specialist had determined that the market rental for Shop 4 was $80,000 per annum or that the market rent was in fact $80,000.
Conduct induce or Capable of Inducing Error?

Again, however, that finding ([187] above) does not provide a sufficient basis for the further finding that the representation was conduct which was misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive.
Conduct is misleading or deceptive only if it induces or is capable of inducing error: see [10(1)] above.
For the reasons set out above at [71] to [85] and [177] to [183], the conduct comprising the Third Tan and Lai Representation was misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive.

In the absence of positive evidence from the Respondents that it had retained a "specialist", that it had retained a "specialist" to determine the market rental for Shop 4, that any such specialist had determined that the market rental for Shop 4 was $80,000 per annum or that the market rent was in fact $80,000, I can only conclude that the Third Tan and Lai Representation was misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive Mr Tan and Mrs Lai.
That conclusion necessarily applies with equal force to the Fourth Tan and Lai Representation.

In the absence of any evidence that the market rent was in fact $80,000, no other conclusion is open other than the Fourth Tan and Lai Representation was misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive Mr Tan and Mrs Lai.

Moreover, for the reasons earlier identified, in contravention of s 53(e) of the TPA, by the Third and Fourth Tan and Lai Representations Dukemaster made a false or misleading representation with respect to the price of goods or services.

(C) 5 MARCH 2007 LETTER
 Thirdly, the ACCC contends that the contents of the 5 March 2007 letter (see [160] above) were misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive because, by that letter, Dukemaster represented to Mr Tan that: it believed that the proposed rent for the renewal of the Second Shop 4 Lease of $90,000 plus GST from 12 April 2007 to 11 April 2008 ("the $90,000 Rent") was very reasonable and below the market value ("the Fifth Tan and Lai Representation"); it had a reasonable basis for believing that the $90,000 Rent was very reasonable and below the market value ("the Sixth Tan and Lai Representation"), 
when, in fact, Dukemaster did not believe and did not have a reasonable basis for believing that the $90,000 Rent was very reasonable and below the market value.

Moreover, the ACCC submitted that Dukemaster had not obtained appropriate valuation advice or evidence in relation to the market rental for Shop 4 from 12 April 2007 to 11 April 2008 and that if it had done so, the market value was approximately $40,500 plus GST.
Again, the two questions arise in the context of s 52 of the TPA.
(1) Was each representation conveyed and (2) if yes to (1), was it misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive?
Representations Conveyed?

The ACCC's complaint concerns the representations that the $90,000 Rent was "very reasonable" and "below the market value" and that Dukemaster had a reasonable basis for believing that the $90,000 Rent was very reasonable and below the market value.
Again, those issues are interlinked.
In its terms, the 5 March 2007 letter made the Third and Fourth Tan and Lai Representations: see [160] above.
As was the position in 2004, Mr Tan and Mrs Lai were not in a position to know whether or not Dukemaster had sought valuation advice or information about comparable rents.
Mr Tan did however ascertain from discussions with other tenants that Dukemaster had put up the rents of other tenants in the Food Court.
Representations Misleading or Deceptive or Likely to Mislead or Deceive?
I have earlier analysed the market rent evidence in 2006 and 2007: see [88] to [111] above.

Dukemaster had not obtained valuation advice or evidence in relation to the market rental for Shop 4 in March 2007 that provided a basis for it holding a belief that the rental it was seeking for Shop 4 was "very reasonable" and "below the market value".
Conduct induce or Capable of Inducing Error?

As explained earlier (see [10(1)] above), if the evidence shows that the opinion expressed by Dukemaster lacked any or any adequate basis, the conduct contravenes s 52 of the TPA only if that conduct induces or is capable of inducing error.
In this context, we are only concerned with the latter because as the summary of facts records (see [162] to [171] above), Mr Tan and Mrs Lai were not induced into error.

If the rent referred to in the 5 March 2007 letter was in fact "very reasonable" and / or "below the market value", then it would not be shown that the conduct complained of by the ACCC could induce or would be capable of inducing error.

In relation to Shop 4, I consider that the conduct complained of is misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive because it is much more probable than not that the $90,000 Rent was not "very reasonable" and / or "below the market value".
Mr Sheehan had earlier expressed an opinion on the current market rent of Shop 4 for the annual period commencing on 12 April 2007: see [162], [165] and [171] above.

In preparation of his 2008 Report, Mr Sheehan was asked the following question in relation to Shops 1 and 2, Shop 4 and Shops 9 and 10: 
Do you remain of the view of Current Market Rent you expressed in each of the rental determination reports dated 26 July 2007 (for Shops 1 & 2, Shop 4 and Shops 9 & 10)?

In his 2008 Report, Mr Sheehan stated: 
Since concluding my assessments of current market rent applicable to each of the Determinations in July 2007, I have not become aware of any information which would affect my assessments.

It is noted that since these Determinations were made, the Lebanese Café (FJ Café), French Patisserie (Duchess Anne French Patisserie) and a Supermarket / Liquor Store have closed, the Soup & Sandwich (Soupfrenzzy) appears to have been rebranded and that the retail complement appears not to have increased in vibrancy.
The Respondents challenged Mr Sheehan's finding outlined in [199] above on two bases.

First, that Mr Sheehan's valuation of rent for Shop 4 for the annual period commencing 12 April 2004 was $43,000 per annum, whereas the valuation at the time of the 26 July 2007 determination and at the time of writing the 2008 Report, (being 6 August 2008), was $40,500.

Secondly, the decrease in rent between 2004 and 2007/2008 was unusual for businesses in the Melbourne CBD based upon the comparative information given to Mr Sheehan at the time of writing his various reports and, further, that they were not satisfied with Mr Sheehan's explanation for such a decrease, particularly noting that the closure of the Supermarket mentioned in [199] above did not occur until late 2007.
I agree with the Respondents' contentions that Mr Sheehan's evidence on his findings outlined in [199] requires close examination.
However, on balance, Mr Sheehan was simply asked whether his assessment in the 2008 Report had changed since making his determination on 26 July 2007 (see [198] above).
His determination on 26 July 2007 was the result of a detailed analysis.
There is nothing to suggest to the contrary.

In responding to questions in cross examination about the reduction in his valuation of the rent between 2004 and 2007/2008, Mr Sheehan stated that he was "very conscious" that his assessment for the rent in 2004 was higher than the rent in July of 2007 and August 2008, that this had "absolutely" caused him to reflect on his findings but ultimately, he believed his valuations to be correct.
Further, as Mr Sheehan's cross examination emphasised, the closures mentioned in [199] had most certainly occurred by August 2008.

The confusion that arose during the course of Mr Sheehan's viva voce evidence was that at one point it seemed to be suggested that these were considerations relevant to his 26 July 2007 determination.
Having read that determination, this is not the case.

As a result, Mr Sheehan's evidence on this point is that on 26 July 2007, when Mr Sheehan made his valuation for Shop 4 for the annual period commencing 12 April 2007, he believed that it was correct on the information provided and that in August 2008 nothing had occurred to increase his valuation (and in fact there were circumstances that could have reduced the value of the tenancy).
The rent proposed to be charged by Dukemaster ($90,000 excluding GST) is more than 120% above the market rent identified by Mr Sheehan ($40,500 excluding GST).

In the absence of positive evidence from the Respondents that the market value of the rent for Shop 4 for the period commencing on 12 April 2007 of $90,000 (excluding GST) was "very reasonable" or "below the market value" (as the 5 March 2007 letter stated it to be), or that Ms Wong genuinely believed the market value of the rent for Shop 4 for that period was greater than $90,000 (excluding GST), I can only conclude that the Fifth and Sixth Tan and Lai Representations were misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive Mr Tan and Mrs Lai.
The $90,000 Rent (excluding GST) was neither "very reasonable" nor "below the market value".

(D) 5 MARCH 2007 CONVERSATION
 Fourthly, the ACCC contends that the contents of the 5 March 2007 conversation (see [161] above) were misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive because, by that conversation, Dukemaster represented to Mr Tan that: $90,000 was the market rent ("the Seventh Tan and Lai Representation"); and Dukemaster had a reasonable basis for expressing its opinion that the $90,000 Rent was the market rental for Shop 4 ("the Eighth Tan and Lai Representation"), 
when, in fact, Dukemaster did not believe and did not have a reasonable basis for believing that the $90,000 Rent was the market value.
Moreover, the ACCC submitted that Dukemaster had not obtained appropriate valuation advice or evidence in relation to the market rental for Shop 4 from 12 April 2007 to 11 April 2008.
Again, the two questions arise in the context of s 52 of the TPA.
(1) Was each representation conveyed and (2) if yes to (1), was it misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive?
Representations Conveyed?
The Seventh and Eighth Tan and Lai Representations were conveyed by the 5 March 2007 conversation: see [161] above.
In fact, the Respondents' amended statement of case admitted that Ms Wong stated that this was the 'correct' amount.
Again, consistent with the legal principles in [10(2)] concerning context, Ms Wong had just delivered the 5 March 2007 letter.
The reference to a 'correct' amount can only mean a reference to the market rental --- therefore the Seventh Tan and Lai Representation was conveyed.
The Eighth Tan and Lai Representation is more straightforward.
It was the evidence of both Mr Tan and Ms Wong that Ms Wong asserted that the $90,000 figure was "reasonable": see [161] above.
Although Mr Tan questioned this figure in the 5 March 2007 conversation, Ms Wong maintained her position.
By so doing, Ms Wong conveyed the Eighth Tan and Lai Representation.
Representations Misleading or Deceptive or Likely to Mislead or Deceive?
As discussed earlier (see [88] to [111] above), the evidence reveals no basis for Dukemaster making the Seventh and Eighth Tan and Lai Representations.

Dukemaster had not obtained valuation evidence or advice in relation to the market rental for Shop 4 for the period from 12 April 2007 that provided a basis for it holding a belief that the rental it was seeking for Shop 4 was "the market rent".
Conduct induce or Capable of Inducing Error?
Again, that finding ([209]) does not provide a sufficient basis for the further finding that each representation was conduct which was misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive.
Conduct is misleading or deceptive only if it induces or is capable of inducing error: see [10(1)] above.
I have addressed the evidence of Mr Sheehan at [196] --- [204] above.

In light of the market evidence considered earlier and in the absence of positive evidence from the Respondents that the market value of the rent for Shop 4 for the period commencing on 12 April 2007 of $90,000 (excluding GST) was "the correct amount" or "the market rent" or that Ms Wong genuinely believed the market value of the rent for Shop 4 for that period was $90,000 (excluding GST), I can only conclude that the Seventh and Eighth Tan and Lai Representations were misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive Mr Tan and Mrs Lai.
(3) UNCONSCIONABLE CONDUCT?
The ACCC also alleged that Dukemaster's conduct was unconscionable within the meaning of s 51AC(1)(a) of the TPA.
A summary of the relevant legal principles is set out in Section B above.

As with Shop 3, given my earlier findings in relation to s 52 of the TPA, and subject to the question of the appropriateness of any declarations and injunctions, a contravention of s 51AC would not otherwise add to or alter the other relief available: see generally Part VI of the TPA.

(A) RENEWAL OF FIRST SHOP 4 LEASE / "NEGOTIATION" OF SECOND SHOP 4 LEASE
 The ACCC's first complaint was that Dukemaster's conduct in relation to the renewal of the First Shop 4 Lease / the "negotiation" of the Second Shop 4 Lease (see Annexure A) was unconscionable within the meaning of s 51AC(1)(a) of the TPA by reason of a number of facts.
As I said earlier (see [127]), s 51AC of the TPA does not require resolution of whether the factors listed by the ACCC are proved or not proved.
The question is whether the supply by Dukemaster of lease premises to Mr Tan and Mrs Lai was, in all the circumstances, unconscionable.
