In assessing that question, the ACCC contends that the matters listed in s 51AC(3)(a), (c), (d), (j) and (k) are relevant.
In all the circumstances, I consider that Dukemaster's conduct in relation to the renewal of the First Shop 4 Lease and the "negotiation" of the Second Shop 4 Lease was unconscionable.

The First and Second Tan and Lai Representations were conveyed in a letter from Dukemaster and were not only misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive them (see Section D(2)(a) above) but: were conveyed to Mr Tan and Mrs Lai who Dukemaster knew had little ability to speak or read English; were intended by Dukemaster to secure a renewal of the lease at a rental for which there was no basis beyond Dukemaster's decision to seek the amount stated; required a response within a period of seven days, when there was no explanation provided by Dukemaster to justify the limited time in which Mr Tan and Mrs Lai could respond.
Dukemaster's conduct was irreconcilable with what is right or reasonable.

If that was not enough, two subsequent events support the conclusion that Dukemaster's conduct in relation to the renewal of the First Shop 4 Lease and the "negotiation" of the Second Shop 4 Lease was unconscionable.

First, when Ms Wong gave Mr Tan the 16 March 2004 letter and after Mr Tan having told her that the rent was very expensive and that if he accepted the $72,000 Rent he did not think he could continue with his business, the Third and Fourth Tan and Lai representations were conveyed to Mr Tan by Ms Wong and were not only misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive he and his wife (see Section D(2)(b) above) but resulted in them not exercising their legal rights to go to an independent rental determination because they feared that what had been told to them by Ms Wong would in fact occur.
As the facts demonstrate (see Section D(2)(b) above), the Third and Fourth Tan and Lai Representations were false.

Secondly, on Mr Tan's second attempt to negotiate a reduction in the rent by seeking a meeting with Ms Wong's manager (see [155] above), he was told by Ms Wong that the manager was overseas in Malaysia and was very busy and had "no time to see [him]" and "there's no negotiation over the rental".
That conduct, in the context of the earlier conduct (see [217]-[218] above) was unfair and unreasonable and contravened s 51AC of the TPA.

(B) RENEWAL OF SECOND SHOP 4 LEASE / "NEGOTIATION" OF THIRD SHOP 4 LEASE
 In all the circumstances, I consider Dukemaster's conduct in relation to the renewal of the Second Shop 4 Lease and the "negotiation" of the Third Shop 4 Lease was unconscionable.

The Fifth to Eighth Tan and Lai Representations were conveyed in letters from Dukemaster or its lawyers or in conversations between Ms Wong and Mr Tan and were not only misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive them (see Section D2(c) and (d) above) but: the letters were conveyed to Mr Tan and Mrs Lai who Dukemaster knew had limited ability to speak or read English; the representations were intended by Dukemaster to secure a renewal of the lease at a rental for which there was no basis beyond Dukemaster's decision to seek the amount stated; both letters required a response within a period of just four days, when there was no explanation provided by Dukemaster to justify the limited time in which Mr Tan could respond.
Dukemaster's conduct was irreconcilable with what is right or reasonable.
Subsequent events support the conclusion that Dukemaster's conduct in relation to the renewal of the Second Shop 4 Lease and the "negotiation" of the Third Shop 4 Lease was unconscionable.

First, after Mr Tan gave notice to Dukemaster that he intended to seek an independent determination of the market rent for Shop 4 and contrary to the practice which had previously existed, Dukemaster's lawyers sent Mr Tan and Mrs Lai a letter of demand on 17 April 2007 for unpaid rent due on 1 April 2007 and threatened that Dukemaster would re-enter and take possession of the shop if the rent remained unpaid.

Secondly, on obtaining the independent market rent determination in late July 2007, Ms Wong refused to give Mr Tan and Mrs Lai a further term on the lease despite having made previous offers (including one in June 2007 --- see [169]) of a further term.
That conduct, in the context of the earlier conduct (see [194] above) was unfair and unreasonable and contravened s 51AC of the TPA.

(4) RELIEF 
 In relation to these contraventions of the TPA, it is appropriate that there be declarations and injunctions.
In addition, pursuant to s 87(1A) (read with s 87(1AA)) of the TPA, the Respondents should refund to Mr Tan and Mrs Lai the amount of rent they were overcharged totalling $91,889.
The sum of $91,889 is calculated by subtracting the market rent from the rent in fact they paid from 21 May 2004 up to and including 24 April 2007.

For the reasons given earlier (see [142] above), on the question of interest, under s 51A of the FCA, Mr Tan and Mrs Lai were entitled to interest on those amounts from the date of payment up to and including 28 February 2009.
That amount of interest is $27,191.
The ACCC also sought interest on the total amount from 1 March 2009.
For the reasons given earlier (see [143] above), the form of the order sought by the ACCC is not appropriate.
Instead, the Respondents should pay Mr Tan and Mrs Lai interest on the amounts overpaid (see [223] above) from and including 1 March 2009.
If the parties are unable to quantify that amount, they may have the matter re-listed.
That leaves one final amount --- the ACCC sought an order that the Respondents pay a further $1,650 for the valuation for the rental for the Third Shop 4 Lease.
I do not consider that this it is an amount that Mr Tan and Mrs Lai should recover from the Respondents.
Mr Tan and Mrs Lai exercised a legal right available to them.
Contrary to the ACCC's submissions that was necessary and, moreover, it achieved its objective.

E. SHOPS 1 AND 2 --- BOXCAR CAFÉ 
(1) FACTS 
 (A) 2000 --- EARLY 2004
 Boxcar Café stands apart from many of the Food Court shops.
The business is owned by Gomax, a company registered in Victoria on 11 September 2002.
Gomax has six (6) directors: Reaky Mi Yee Ho ("Mrs Ho") and her husband Roddy Fu Wa Ho, Ronald Yue Lung Ma ("Mr Ma") and his wife Kam Ping Lau, Yoon Choong Lai and Maryanne Shin Quan Lau.
The directors had previously operated successful portable food stalls at various markets.
Boxcar Café is the company's sole business activity.
Mrs Ho was born in Hong Kong in 1960 where she worked as a tailor for over 20 years.
In 2000, she came to Australia with her husband and daughter.
She speaks fluent Cantonese and good Mandarin.
Her ability to read and write English is limited and she relies upon her husband to interpret and write documents relating to the business.
She gave evidence through a Cantonese Interpreter.
One of the other directors, Mr Ma was also born in Hong Kong.
In July 2000, he came to Australia with his wife.
He is fluent in Cantonese and can speak and read English well.
He holds a Bachelor of Applied Science and is employed as the Team Leader of the advisor remuneration team at a large insurance company.
In early to middle 2002, the directors met and decided to contribute to buy a café and to register Gomax as a company to own the business.
In early October 2002, Mrs Ho and Mr Ma discovered the Boxcar Café in the Food Court was for sale.
Mrs Ho went to the Paramount Centre and sat in the Food Court for one week from 7:00am until 3:00pm.
The other Gomax directors also visited the Paramount Centre to observe the business.
From late October to early December 2002, Mr Ma and Mrs Ho negotiated with the then owner of Boxcar Café, Meng, to purchase the business.
On 27 October 2002, Mrs Ho signed a contract of sale on behalf of Gomax to purchase the business subject to a successful trial period.
The trial period was from 25 November 2002 until 7 December 2002.
At the end of the trial period, Mrs Ho, Mr Lai and Mr Ma met with Ms Wong to obtain Dukemaster's approval to take over the lease.
At that time, the lease still had two years to run with an option for a further term of four years.
To the extent that the leasing history was not in dispute, it is summarised in Annexure A.
The transfer of the lease was signed by Mr Ma and Mrs Ho on about 20 December 2002.
Gomax purchased the Boxcar business for about $340,000.
Mrs Ho paid one third of the purchase price (secured by a mortgage against her home) with Mr Ma (also secured against his family home) and Mr Lai each paying one third.
Gomax took over Boxcar on 20 December 2002.
Boxcar Café sells sandwiches, hot and cold drinks, hot and cold breakfasts and has a hot and cold food bar.
For the first seven months of trading (until around July 2003), Mrs Ho and Mr Ma worked in the business with the assistance of nine part time staff.
After that time, Mrs Ho managed the day to day operations of Boxcar Café.
The directors of Gomax met and continue to meet about every three months to make the key decisions about the business.
Events then shift towards the end of 2003.
There is a dispute about the circumstances in which Gomax gave notice to Dukemaster at the end of 2003 that it wished to renew the lease.
According to Mrs Ho, it was during a conversation in late 2003 that Ms Wong reminded Mrs Ho that Gomax's lease was due to expire in January 2004.

Mrs Ho says that the conversation was in Cantonese and that Ms Wong told her that the end of the lease was coming up in January, Gomax should have told her half a year ago in writing that they wanted to renew the lease, she had the right to not renew the lease but was prepared to renew it if Gomax wanted to.

According to Mrs Ho, when she told Ms Wong that Gomax did want to renew the lease, Ms Wong asked that Mrs Ho write a letter to her confirming that fact and, although Mrs Ho could not produce the letter, her evidence was that Mr Ma drafted a letter for her which she sent to Ms Wong.
The Respondents' position in relation to this series of events was not consistent.

Initially, the Respondents' amended points of defence contended that Mrs Ho telephoned Ms Wong and, in Cantonese, asked for a renewal of the lease which request Ms Wong acceded to but asked Mrs Ho to make the request in writing.

The Respondents' amended points of defence contended that it was during this conversation that Ms Wong offered to renew the lease for a rental of $72,000 plus GST, that the offer was accepted by Mrs Ho and that subsequently Dukemaster received a letter from Mr Ma, on behalf of Gomax, indicating Gomax's desire to renew the lease.

Ms Wong's later evidence was that first, on 27 November 2003, Dukemaster sent a letter to Gomax in the following terms ("27 November 2003 letter"): 
We note the lease for the above shops will expire on 22/01/2004.
Please advise by 5.00pm 8 th December, 2003 whether you will exercise the option for a further term of 4 years.
Should you wish to exercise the option for a further term, we advise the rent for the above shops will be $72,000 pa plus GST commencing 23/01/2004.
We believe the new rent is very reasonable and below the market value .
If you object to our proposed rent, the matter will proceed to valuation in accordance with clause RC3.2 of the lease contract.
(Emphasis added).
Mrs Ho does not recall this letter.

Ms Wong's handwritten note on Dukemaster's copy of the letter reads: 
Tenant requested new lease of 1 term of 3 years & further term of 3 years with commencing rent $72,000 pa + GST for 1 st year of 1 st term.

12/12/03
 
 
Ms Wong's evidence was that note recorded a later conversation she had with Mrs Ho.
I do not accept the Respondents' first version of events.
It is highly improbable that Mrs Ho would have contacted Ms Wong and then asked for a rent increase and to a specified sum as large as $72,000 plus GST.

Not only did Ms Wong confirm Mrs Ho's evidence that Mrs Ho did not know at the time of the conversation that she had to renew the lease but the contents of the subsequent letter sent by Gomax did not refer to the amount of the rent at all, let alone agreement that the rent would be $72,000 plus GST.
In relation to the second version of events, there are two issues in dispute.

First, what was the first event - the 27 November 2003 letter or a conversation between Ms Wong and Mrs Ho - and secondly, was a second term of three years raised during the conversation whenever it occurred.

I find that it is more likely than not the 27 November 2003 letter was the first step and that it was the receipt of that letter that prompted an enquiry by Mrs Ho about whether Dukemaster was prepared to grant a new lease of one term for three years and a further term of three years.

It was then during the subsequent conversation that they discussed a commencing rent of $72,000 per annum plus GST for 1 st year of 1 st term in place of a renewal for a further term of four years as then existed (as is recorded on Dukemaster's copy of that letter: see [237] above).

In late December 2003 or early January 2004, Dukemaster instructed its lawyers to prepare lease documents for the new lease of one term for three years and a further term of three years with commencing rent $72,000 per annum plus GST for 1 st year of 1 st term.
On 15 January 2004, the lease documents were handed to Mrs Ho.

The covering letter stated, in part: 
...
If you have a solicitor acting for you in this matter we suggest that you take the enclosed documents to your solicitor as soon as possible.

If you execute and return the Lease to us without advice from a solicitor our client will treat your execution and return of the Lease as acknowledgement by you that you are satisfied with all the terms and conditions in the Lease.

Having made the findings in [238] above about what transpired in late 2003, it follows that I reject Mrs Ho's evidence that she was surprised to find in January 2004 that the lease contained a further term of three years.

I do however accept that Mrs Ho did not understand the difference between renewal of the old lease and the granting of a new lease but that she and the other directors of Gomax signed the lease on the basis that the $72,000 Rent was acceptable to them in light of the additional lease term.
On 20 February 2004, Mr Ma and Mrs Ho signed the new lease on behalf of Gomax.
The commencement date was 23 January 2004.
On 12 March 2004, Gomax received written confirmation from Dukemaster that it had signed the new lease and received a copy of the signed lease.
Again, to the extent that the history was not in dispute, it is summarised in Annexure A.

(B) 2004 --- 2007 INCLUDING 3 JANUARY 2007 LETTER AND JANUARY 2007 CONVERSATION
 By late 2004, Gomax's takings had fallen by about 25%.
The position continued to decline during 2005 and 2006.
Initially, some blame for this decline was attributed to the opening of two new shops that competed with Gomax for customers.
Such blame seems misdirected.
In cross examination it became apparent that one of these stores had opened in 2003, and the other opened in late 2006.
However, regardless of the reasons for decline in profits, it is clear that such a decline occurred.
In order to reduce Boxcar's costs, Mrs Ho reduced both the number of part time staff working in the café and the hours of trading.
The Gomax directors decided to try and sell the business.
All the Gomax directors agreed that they would stop receiving any money from the business to fund the loans they had taken out to purchase the business.
In August 2006, Mrs Ho asked Mr Ma to write a letter to Dukemaster confirming that Gomax wanted to exercise the option to renew the lease for another term of three years.

On or about 21 August 2006, Mrs Ho hand delivered the following letter to Mr Sant: 
I am writing on behalf of all directors of ... [Gomax], to confirm that we would like to exercise the option for another term of 3 years, as stated in the lease.
Thank you kindly for your attention!
Mrs Ho's evidence was that she wanted to renew the lease because she knew that it would be easier to sell the business if there was a longer lease.
The date is important.
It is the date immediately preceding the 22 August 2006 meeting between Ms Wong and Mr Hii: see [89] to [100] above.
Gomax received no immediate response to its letter.
What then happened was in dispute.

Mrs Ho's evidence was that in October 2006 she telephoned Ms Wong and asked her why she had not responded to her 21 August 2006 letter and that Ms Wong responded saying that she did not have any idea how much rent they should charge Boxcar and that she would get someone to tell her how much to charge.
Mrs Ho's further evidence was that she responded by asking Ms Wong to let her know as soon as she could.
Ms Wong did not recall that this conversation.
Significantly, Mrs Ho was not cross examined about the fact or contents of the conversation.
I accept Mrs Ho's evidence in relation to this conversation.

Despite the letter of 21 August and the October 2006 conversation, Dukemaster did not address the issue of the rent for the exercised option for Shops 1 and 2 until 3 January 2007 when Mr Sant hand delivered the following letter to Mrs Ho: 
Thank you for your exercise of option for further term of 3 years in relation to the above lease.

We note the current lease expires on 22 nd January 2007 and we advise the following:
 
 
Commencement Date: 23 rd January 2007
 
 
Rent per annum 1 st year $96000.00 (plus GST)
 
 2 nd year: To CPI
 
 3 rd year: To CPI
 
 
Please advise by 5.00pm 10 th January 2007 whether you accept this offer.
We believe the new rent is very reasonable and below the market value.
If you object to our proposed rent, the matter will proceed to valuation in accordance with clause 5-16(A) of the lease contract.
If the above proposals are acceptable to you please advise us by signing below and return a copy to us by 5pm 10 th January 2007.
We will instruct our solicitors to prepare the lease and forward it to you for your perusal and execution.
If you have any queries in relation to this matter, please contact this office.

PATRICIA WONG 
 
 GENERAL MANAGER 
 
 
I have read and accept the above terms & conditions of the above lease:
 
 
_______________________
 
Signature
 
Date:
 
 
(Emphasis added).

The form and content of this letter (subject to different particulars) was the same as the letter Dukemaster sent to the Korean Lunch Box on the same date (see [35] above) and to East on Paramount on 5 March 2007 (see [160] above).
Mrs Ho read the letter and understood the substance of it.
This was the first time that Dukemaster had told Gomax about the fact and size of the rent increase.
Mrs Ho was shocked.
She had expected an increase but not an increase of that size.
At that time, Gomax was paying $83,000 rent per annum plus GST.
Mrs Ho telephoned Mr Ma and told him about the letter.
Shortly after that telephone conversation, the Gomax directors met to discuss the letter and decided that Mrs Ho should try and talk to Ms Wong about not raising the rent so high.
On 9 January 2007, Mrs Ho telephoned Ms Wong to make an appointment to meet with her to discuss the 3 January 2007 letter.
Ms Wong agreed to meet her the next day.
Before Mrs Ho met with Ms Wong she learned that she could ask for a 21 day cooling off period.
Ultimately, there was no dispute that Mrs Ho met with Ms Wong on 10 January 2007, being the last day for Gomax to respond to the 3 January 2007 letter.
I say ultimately because the Respondents' amended points of defence in fact denied "that any meeting was requested by Mrs Ho or [was] held.

" By the time of trial, the Respondents' position had changed - there was no dispute that Mrs Ho met with Ms Wong on or about 10 January 2007 but they disputed Mrs Ho's evidence of the contents of that conversation.
Mrs Ho's oral evidence was she asked Ms Wong if she could reduce the rent and Ms Wong replied saying that she would not reduce the rental and that the rent was correct.

Mrs Ho's evidence was that she told Ms Wong that "the business at the time was very bad, not many customer, so it's impossible that the rental was that expensive" to which Ms Wong again said that the rent was correct, that the Paramount Centre was a good centre and that when you compared the Paramount Centre to QV, the Paramount Centre was as good a centre.
Mrs Ho said she responded saying that it was impossible to compare the Paramount Centre with QV and that there was a lot more traffic at QV because they had a lot more shops there.
Mrs Ho said that Ms Wong again said that the rent was correct and that there was no other way that she could help her.

Mrs Ho's evidence was that she told Ms Wong that she would go home to consider and that she was entitled to a 21 day cooling off period to which Ms Wong responded that it was "okay for [her] to go home to have a think".
Mrs Ho was not cross examined about the contents of this conversation.

Ms Wong's evidence was that the conversation at the meeting with Mrs Ho was very brief and that Mrs Ho said that the rent was a bit high, asked whether Dukemaster could lower the rent and then asked for more time to consider the lease.
Ms Wong agreed that she said that they should have 21 days to review the lease and gave evidence that she told Mrs Ho to take her time.
I accept Mrs Ho's version of what transpired at the meeting on 10 January 2007.
At that time, the principal issue was the size of the rent increase.
On 30 January 2007, a further meeting was held between Ms Wong and Mrs Ho.
There is no dispute that the meeting took place.
The dispute concerned what transpired at the meeting.
Mrs Ho's evidence was that at this meeting she asked Ms Wong again to see whether she could lower the rent and Ms Wong responded by saying, "There's nothing I can do.
I can't help you.
The only thing I could help you that I would give you a few more years' lease, so that it would be easier for you to sell the business".
Mrs Ho says she replied that "If you give me longer lease, but the rent was so expensive, I still have to sell the business.
There's no potential buyer would like to buy a business, which does not generate profit.

" At the end of this exchange, Mrs Ho said that Ms Wong wrote on the 3 January 2007 letter saying that the lease would be five by five, showed the letter with the handwritten annotation to her and said, "That's the only thing I could help you.

" Ms Wong then explained to Mrs Ho that there would be a five by five lease with a market rent review in the fourth year and another market review two years later so that within these years, the scale of the rental increase would not be that big.
After that, Mrs Ho said Ms Wong signed the letter, she said to Ms Wong that she was not willing to sign the letter but she had no option.
Mrs Ho said that she then signed the letter after she said to Ms Wong that if she signs, she dies and if she does not sign, she also dies.
Ms Wong then copied the letter and gave her a copy of it.

Ms Wong's version of the meeting was that Mrs Ho called to make an appointment to see her again towards the end of January and that when she came she asked whether Dukemaster could lower the rent to which Ms Wong replied that they thought the rent was right and that Dukemaster could not lower the rent.
The dispute commences at this point.
Ms Wong's version was that Mrs Ho spoke about selling her business and asked whether she could have a further term.
Ms Wong's version was that Mrs Ho asked for a new long lease to which Ms Wong agreed and then Mrs Ho pressed for that offer to be put in writing straight away.
It was the last part, the request for it to be put in writing straight away, that was said to explain why Ms Wong wrote the offer on the 3 January 2007 letter there and then.
Ms Wong's evidence was that Mrs Ho pressed for the letter so that it could be shown to her shareholders.
This suggestion was never put to Mrs Ho and should be rejected.

Finally, it was common ground that Ms Wong explained the rent reviews for the first year, second year and fourth year of the lease term and that the review for the fourth year of each term and the first year of the second term would be a market review as distinct from CPI increases in the other years.
In any event, on 5 February 2007, Dukemaster's lawyers sent a letter to Gomax enclosing the lease in duplicate, the disclosure statement and the retail leases information brochure.

The letter contained the usual closing paragraph: 
If you have a solicitor acting for you in this matter we suggest that you take the enclosed documents to your solicitor as soon as possible.

If you execute and return the Lease to us without advice from a solicitor our client will treat your execution and return of the Lease as acknowledgement by you that you are satisfied with all the terms and conditions in the Lease.
On receiving the letter and the documents, Mrs Ho decided to hold off signing the new lease for as long as possible.
Mrs Ho continued to pay the rent payable under the old lease.
No one from Dukemaster spoke to her about paying the old rent although Mr Sant did ask her on one occasion when she would return the new lease.

On 22 March 2007, Gomax received a letter from Dukemaster's lawyers in the following terms: 
...
 
 
We are instructed that despite several requests from our client, you have not signed and returned the Lease documents forwarded to you on the 5 February 2007.
By your conduct, you have repudiated our client's offer to you of the new Lease.
You have further confirmed your repudiation by failing to pay our client the rent of $8,000.00 per calendar month plus GST (i.e.
$96,000.00 per annum plus GST).

You have instead chosen to pay the rent of $6,943.10 per calendar month (inclusive of GST) which we note is the rent payable by you during the third and final year of the Lease which expired on the 22 January 2007.
Our client has now instructed us to inform you that due to your above-mentioned conduct, it is withdrawing its said offer of a new Lease to you.

Your repudiation of our client's said offer made it unnecessary for our client to withdraw its offer but we have been instructed to clearly put it to you that our client's offer of the new Lease has been withdrawn.
Our client further instructs us that you have exercised your option for the further term of three (3) years under the Lease dated the 20 February 2004.

Pursuant to the option exercised by you, we now enclose herewith the following: - 
 
 
...
 
 
We will prepare the Lease and forward to you or your Solicitor when the first year rent for the Renewed Lease is agreed to by you and our client.
Our client has proposed the $96,000.00 per annum plus GST for the first year of the Renewed Lease.
Our client is of the opinion that the rent of $96,000.00 per annum plus GST is the market rent for the premises.
We are instructed that you have so far not agreed to the rent proposed by our client.
Under Clause 5.16A of the Lease , if both parties cannot agree on the rent, then the rent is to be determined by a Valuer appointed by the President of the Australian Institute of Valuers.
Our client requires your response to our client's proposed rent of $96,000.00 per annum plus GST by the 26 March 2007 .
If we do not have your response by the 26 March 2007, out client proposes that the rent be determined by a Valuer.

...
 
(Emphasis in original).
Mr Ma explained the letter to Mrs Ho.
She understood that she still had a three year lease.
Mrs Ho told the other Gomax directors that she would continue to pay the old rent in the hope that Dukemaster would lower the rent.

At about this time, Mrs Ho met with the owners of two other shops in the Food Court (Mrs Tan of East on Paramount and Irene Watt of Chine on Paramount) and they decided to share the cost of a rental determination as described in [162] above.

On 24 March 2007, Mrs Ho delivered a letter addressed to Dukemaster in the following terms: 
This letter is to advise that the rental charges of $96,000.00 per annum offered in the Renewed Lease to [Gomax] is NOT accepted.

On about 17 April 2007, Gomax received a letter from Dukemaster's lawyers in the following terms: 
We are instructed that you are in default under the Lease as you have failed to pay the monthly rent of $7,107.45 (inclusive of GST) due on the 1 April 2007.
We are further instructed that no arrangements have been made by you with the Landlord to pay the outstanding amount despite request to you by our client for payment.
Please note that the April rent is based on the final year's rent of the expired Lease until you and our client come to an agreement on the rent for the first year of the Renewed Lease.

Notice is hereby given that unless outstanding amount totalling $7,107.45 is paid by 3.30pm on or before Tuesday, 24 April 2007, our client will re-enter and take possession of the premises without any further notice to you.

In the event that our client re-enter (sic), and take possession of the premises, we have instructions to issue legal proceedings against you to recover all damages suffered by our client as a result of your defaulting on the Lease.
We advise that the Landlord is also entitled to charge interests (sic) on the overdue moneys.
Our client reserves all its rights under the Lease.
The letter is in the same terms as the letter sent to the owners of East on Paramount on the same date with the same deadline: see [166] above.
As with East on Paramount (see [167] above), this was the first time that Gomax had received a letter of demand for late payment of rent and shortly after receiving the letter, Mrs Ho paid the rent.
As discussed previously, Mr Sheehan released the rental determinations in late July 2007: see [171] above.
Mr Sheehan determined the rent for Shops 1 and 2 for the period from 23 January 2007 to 22 January 2008 at $65,000 per annum plus GST.
The rent charged by Dukemaster ($96,000 excluding GST) is more than 45% above the market rent identified by Mr Sheehan ($65,000 excluding GST).
About two weeks later, Mr Sant hand delivered to Mrs Ho a copy of the new lease with the annual rent in accordance with the determination by Mr Sheehan.
The lease did not contain any further terms.
Mrs Ho and Mr Ma each took the issue up with Ms Wong.
Mrs Ho telephoned Mrs Wong.
Mrs Ho's evidence was that Ms Wong told Mrs Ho that there would be no further term because the rent was much lower.
Ms Wong's evidence was that she told Mrs Ho that there would be no further term because the renewal option was not exercised.
Mr Ma's evidence was that Ms Wong told him that because Gomax had refused to take up the lease at $96,000, she was not going to extend the lease any more for Gomax.
Ms Wong's evidence was that she told Mr Ma the same thing she told Mrs Ho --- that there was no further term because the renewal option was not exercised.
I reject Ms Wong's evidence in relation to both these conversations.
The reason given by her --- namely that there would be no further term because the renewal option was not exercised --- is improbable.
That is precisely what occurred in 2004.
The only difference this time was that Gomax had rejected Dukemaster's stipulated rent and gone to a rental determination which was unsuccessful from Dukemaster's perspective.
Mrs Ho did not sign the new lease.
She hoped Dukemaster would agree to provide a further term.
No one from Dukemaster approached Mrs Ho or Gomax about the failure of them to sign the new lease.
Attempts by Gomax to sell the Boxcar Café have been unsuccessful.
Mrs Ho's evidence is that it will be very difficult to get a good price for the business because there is no guarantee of a further term when the current lease expires in 2010.
The two issues --- not agreeing to a higher rent and the lack of an additional term --- are interrelated.

As Mrs Ho said in her affidavit evidence: 
Gomax was in a no-win situation: if we had agreed to the higher rent we would have paid too much as the rental determination showed that the amount Dukemaster tried to charge us was much too high, yet now we are paying a fair rent, we cannot get any further term on Gomax's lease.
In either event, the business would not have been saleable for a good price.
(2) CONDUCT MISLEADING OR DECEPTIVE OR LIKELY TO MISLEAD OR DECEIVE?
The ACCC had a number of complaints.
Each complaint dealt with separate representations.
Although some of the representations contain common elements, each must be considered separately because each is said to constitute a separate contravention of s 52 of the TPA.

(A) LATE 2003 CONVERSATION
 First, the ACCC contended that the statements made by Ms Wong to Mrs Ho in late 2003 (see [234 and [235] above) were misleading and deceptive because Dukemaster represented to Mrs Ho that the time for Gomax to exercise its option to renew the lease for Shops 1 had 2 had expired ("the First Gomax Representation"), when, in fact, the time for Gomax to exercise its option had not expired because as a result of Dukemaster giving Gomax written notice under s 18(3) of the Retail Tenancies Reform Act 1998 (Vic) ("the RTRA"), the time for Gomax to exercise its option to renew the lease continued until at least six months after the requisite notice was eventually given.
Two questions arise in the context of s 52 of the TPA.
(1) Was the representation conveyed and (2) if yes to (1), was it misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive?
Representations Conveyed?
The First Gomax Representation was conveyed by the late 2003 conversation: see [234] and [235] above.
Representations Misleading or Deceptive or Likely to Mislead or Deceive?
The representation was false.

As the Respondents' Counsel submitted, the lease for Shops 1 and 2 (which was entered into in 2000) was a lease subject to the RTRA: see s 4(1), (2) and (4) of the RTRA and ss 2(5) and 11(1) and Pt 14 of the Retail Leases Act .

Section 18 of the RTRA (in force in late 2003) provided: 
(1) In this section "option" does not include the statutory option.

(2) If a retail premises lease contains an option exercisable by the tenant to renew the lease for a further term, the lease must state---
 
 
(a) the date until which the option is exercisable; and
 
 
(b) the manner in which the option is to be exercised; and
 
 
(c) the terms and conditions upon which the lease is renewable under the option; and
 
 
(d) the manner in which the rent payable during the term for which the lease is renewed is to be determined.

(3) If a retail premises lease contains an option exercisable by the tenant to renew the lease for a further term, the landlord must notify the tenant in writing of the date after which the option is no longer exercisable---
 
 
(a) at least 6 months; and
 
 
(b) no more than 12 months---
 
 
before that date but is not required to do so if the tenant exercises, or purports to exercise, the option before being notified of the date.

(3A) If a retail premises lease contains an option exercisable by the tenant to renew the lease for a further term, the only circumstances in which the option is not exercisable is if---
 
 
(a) the tenant has not remedied any default under the lease about which the landlord has given the tenant written notice; or
 
 
(b) the tenant has persistently defaulted under the lease throughout its term and the landlord has given the tenant written notice of the defaults.

(4) If sub-section (3) requires the landlord to notify the tenant but the landlord fails to do so within the time specified by that sub-section---
 
 
(a) the retail premises lease is taken to provide that the date after which the option is no longer exercisable is instead 6 months after the landlord notifies the tenant as required; and
 
 
(b) if that date is after the term of the lease ends, the lease continues until that date (on the same terms and conditions as applied immediately before the lease term ends); and (c) the tenant, whether or not the landlord has by then notified the tenant as required, may give written notice to the landlord terminating the lease from a specified day that is---
 
 
(i) on or after the date on which the term of the lease ends; and
 
 
(ii) before the date until which the lease would otherwise have continued because of paragraph (b).
(5) If the tenant gives the landlord a notice of termination under sub-section (4)(c), the lease terminates on the day specified in the notice.

(6) If an option to renew is exercised because of subsection (4)(b) after the term of the lease ends, the lease for the further term commences on the expiry of the previous lease, disregarding for this purpose any period during which that lease continued because of that sub-section.
(7) The amendments made to this section by section 105 of the Retail Leases Act 2003 only have effect from 1 November 2003.
The lease for Shops 1 and 2 contained "an option exercisable by the tenant to renew the lease for a further term": see Annexure A.
And contrary to Ms Wong's representations, the time for the exercise of that option had not expired because, contrary to s 18 of the RTRA, Dukemaster had not given notice in accordance with s 18.
Conduct Induce or Capable of Inducing Error?

Again, however, that finding ([269] and [270] above) does not provide a sufficient basis for the further finding that the representation was conduct which was misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive.
Conduct is misleading or deceptive only if it induces or is capable of inducing error: see [10(1)] above.
In relation to this conduct, it did induce error.
Mrs Ho understood that the time for the exercise of the option had expired when it had not.

Unsurprisingly, it was never put to Mrs Ho or Mr Ma that the representation (if made) would not have induced error because they were somehow aware of s 18 of the RTRA and the obligations it imposed on Dukemaster, obligations which Dukemaster did not discharge.
For those reasons, the conduct comprising the First Gomax Representation was misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive.

(B) 3 JANUARY 2007 LETTER
 Secondly, the ACCC contends that the contents of the 3 January 2007 letter (see [247] above) were misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive because, by that letter, Dukemaster represented to Gomax that: it believed that the proposed rent for the Third Shops 1 and 2 Lease (again, as pleaded by the ACCC) of $96,000 plus GST from 23 January 2007 to 22 January 2008 ("the $96,000 Rent") was very reasonable and below the market value ("the Second Gomax Representation"); it had a reasonable basis for believing that the $96,000 Rent was very reasonable and below the market value ("the Third Gomax Representation"), 
when, in fact, Dukemaster did not believe and did not have a reasonable basis for believing that the $96,000 Rent was very reasonable and below the market value.

Moreover, the ACCC submitted that Dukemaster had not obtained appropriate valuation advice or evidence in relation to the market rental for Shops 1 and 2 from 23 January 2007 to 22 January 2008 and that if it had done so, the market value was approximately $65,000 plus GST.
Again, the two questions arise in the context of s 52 of the TPA.
(1) Was each representation conveyed and (2) if yes to (1), was it misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive?
Representations Conveyed?

The ACCC's complaint concerns the representations that the $96,000 Rent was "very reasonable" and "below the market value" and that Dukemaster had a reasonable basis for believing that the $96,000 Rent was very reasonable and below the market value.
Again, those issues are interlinked.
In its terms, the 3 January 2007 letter made the Second and Third Gomax Representations: see [247] above.
None of the principals of Gomax were in a position to know whether or not Dukemaster had sought valuation advice or information about comparable rents.
Mrs Ho did however ascertain from discussions with other tenants that Dukemaster had put up the rents of other tenants in the Food Court.
Representations Misleading or Deceptive or Likely to Mislead or Deceive?
I have earlier analysed the market rent evidence in 2006 and 2007: see [88] to [111] above.

Dukemaster had not obtained valuation advice or evidence in relation to the market rental for Shops 1 and 2 in January 2007 that provided a basis for it holding a belief that the rental it was seeking for Shops 1 and 2 was "very reasonable" and "below the market value".
Conduct Induce or Capable of Inducing Error?

As explained earlier (see [10(1)] above), if the evidence shows that the opinion expressed by Dukemaster lacked any or any adequate basis, the conduct contravenes s 52 of the TPA only if that conduct induces or is capable of inducing error.
In this context, we are concerned with the latter because as the summary of facts records (see [259] to [264] above), Gomax was not induced into error.

If the rent referred to in the 3 January 2007 letter was in fact "very reasonable" and / or "below the market value", then it would not be shown that the conduct complained of by the ACCC could induce or would be capable of inducing error.

In relation to Shops 1 and 2, I consider that the conduct complained of is misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive because it is much more probable than not that the $96,000 Rent was not "very reasonable" and / or "below the market value".
Mr Sheehan had earlier expressed an opinion on the current market rent of Shops 1 and 2 for the annual period commencing on 23 January 2007: see [259], [262] and [263] above.
In that report, he described Shops 1 and 2 as "situated in the northwest section of the Little Bourke Street level.
In comparison to the other food services outlets within the [F]ood [C]ourt, [Shops 1 and 2] has a wide frontage of about 15 m which provides for a double outlet width.
[Shops 1 and 2] includes an extensive service counter behind which is a partition wall section dividing the food preparation, cooking, washing and cool room area ...
The condition of improvements as inspected appeared well maintained ...".

In preparation of his 2008 Report, Mr Sheehan was asked the following question in relation to Shops 1 and 2, Shop 4 and Shops 9 and 10: 
Do you remain of the view of Current Market Rent you expressed in each of the rental determination reports dated 26 July 2007 (for Shops 1 & 2, Shop 4 and Shops 9 & 10)?

In his 2008 Report, Mr Sheehan stated: 
Since concluding my assessments of current market rent applicable to each of the Determinations in July 2007, I have not become aware of any information which would affect my assessments.

It is noted that since these Determinations were made, the Lebanese Café (FJ Café), French Patisserie (Duchess Anne French Patisserie) and a Supermarket / Liquor Store have closed, the Soup & Sandwich (Soupfrenzzy) appears to have been rebranded and that the retail complement appears not to have increased in vibrancy.
I addressed the substance of this evidence at [200] --- [201].
The rent proposed to be charged by Dukemaster ($96,000 excluding GST) is more than 45% above the market rent identified by Mr Sheehan ($65,000 excluding GST): see [262] above.

In the absence of positive evidence from the Respondents that the market value of the rent for Shops 1 and 2 for the annual period commencing on 23 January 2007 of $96,000 (excluding GST) was "very reasonable" or "below the market value" (as the 3 January 2007 letter stated it to be), or that Ms Wong genuinely believed the market value of the rent for Shops 1 and 2 for that period was greater than $96,000 (excluding GST), I can only conclude that the Second and Third Gomax Representations were misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive Gomax.
The $96,000 Rent (excluding GST) was neither "very reasonable" nor "below the market value".

(C) 10 JANUARY 2007 CONVERSATION
 Thirdly, the ACCC contends that the contents of the 10 January 2007 conversation (see [249] - [252] above) were misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive because, by that conversation, Dukemaster represented to Gomax that: $96,000 was the market rent ("the Fourth Gomax Representation"); and Dukemaster had a reasonable basis for expressing its opinion that the $96,000 Rent was the market rental for Shops 1 and 2 ("the Fifth Gomax Representation"), 
when, in fact, Dukemaster did not believe and did not have a reasonable basis for believing that the $96,000 Rent was the market value.

Moreover, the ACCC submitted that Dukemaster had not obtained appropriate valuation advice or evidence in relation to the market rental for Shops 1 and 2 from 23 January 2007 to 22 January 2008 and that if it had done so, the market value was approximately $65,000 plus GST.
Again, the two questions arise in the context of s 52 of the TPA.
(1) Was each representation conveyed and (2) if yes to (1), was it misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive?
Representations Conveyed?
The Fourth and Fifth Gomax Representations were conveyed by the 10 January 2007 conversation: see [249] - [252] above.
Representations Misleading or Deceptive or Likely to Mislead or Deceive?
As discussed earlier (see [278] above), the evidence reveals no basis for Dukemaster making the Fourth and Fifth Gomax Representations.

Dukemaster had not obtained valuation evidence or advice in relation to the market rental for Shops 1 and 2 for the period from 23 January 2007 to 22 January 2008 that provided a basis for it holding a belief that the rental it was seeking for Shop 4 was "the market rent".
Conduct Induce or Capable of Inducing Error?
Again, that finding ([289]) does not provide a sufficient basis for the further finding that each representation was conduct which was misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive.
Conduct is misleading or deceptive only if it induces or is capable of inducing error: see [10(1)] above.

However, in light of the market evidence considered earlier (see [278] above) and in the absence of positive evidence from the Respondents that the market value of the rent for Shops 1 and 2 for the annual period commencing on 23 January 2007 of $96,000 (excluding GST) was "the correct amount" or "the market rent" or that Ms Wong genuinely believed the market value of the rent for Shop 1 and 2 for that period was $96,000 (excluding GST), I can only conclude that the Fourth and Fifth Gomax Representations were misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive Gomax.
(3) UNCONSCIONABLE CONDUCT?
The ACCC also alleged that Dukemaster's conduct was unconscionable within the meaning of s 51AC(1)(a) of the TPA.
A summary of the relevant legal principles is set out in Section B above.

Again, given my earlier findings in relation to s 52 of the TPA, and subject to the question of the appropriateness of any declarations and injunctions, a contravention of s 51AC would not otherwise add to or alter the other relief available: see generally Part VI of the TPA.

(A) FIRST RENEWAL
 The ACCC's first complaint was that Dukemaster's conduct in relation to the renewal of the Shops 1 and 2 Lease in late 2003 / early 2004 (see Annexure A) was unconscionable within the meaning of s 51AC(1)(a) of the TPA by reason of a number of facts.
As I said earlier (see [127]), s 51AC of the TPA does not require resolution of whether the factors listed by the ACCC are proved or not proved.
The question is whether the supply by Dukemaster of those lease premises to Gomax was, in all the circumstances, unconscionable.
In assessing that question, the ACCC contends that the matters listed in s 51AC(3)(a), (c), (d) and (k) are relevant.

Notwithstanding that the First Gomax Representation was conveyed and was misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive Gomax, in all the circumstances, I do not consider that Dukemaster's conduct in relation to the Renewal of the First Shops 1 and 2 Lease and the "negotiation" of the Second Shops 1 and 2 Lease was unconscionable.
The fact that the "partners" in Gomax decided to incorporate Gomax to conduct the business cannot be and is not determinative.
Similarly, Mrs Ho's limited command of written and spoken English is not determinative.
There were other directors of Gomax.
The other directors Gomax included highly educated people who met "about every three months to make the key decisions about the business".
Gomax had the ability and the means to protect its interests.
The failure of Dukemaster to comply with the RTRA is a serious matter.

However, I am not satisfied that having regard to the composition of the board of directors of Gomax and the manner in which Gomax made key decisions about its business, that Dukemaster's conduct contravened s 51AC of the TPA.

In my view, s 51AC of the Act is not intended to provide a safety net for those corporations and individuals who have the ability and means (relative to the supplier) to deal with lease issues and yet, for reasons unexplained, fail to take any or sufficient steps to protect themselves or who make a commercial decision which ultimately proves to be the wrong decision.

In this case, those "lease issues" included the requirement that Dukemaster give notice for exercise of the renewal in accordance with s 18 of the RTRA and the decision to accept rent of $72,000 under a new lease with an additional term instead of a renewal of the existing lease with a right to a rental determination.
In my view, although Dukemaster's conduct was contrary to s 18 of the RTRA, it cannot be said that that conduct contravened s 51AC of the TPA.
It was not irreconcilable with what is right or reasonable in the manner described by Foster J in Allphones Retail (No.2) [2009] FCA 17: see [17] above.

(B) SECOND RENEWAL
 Although I do not consider that Dukemaster's conduct in relation to the First Renewal of Shops 1 and 2 Lease was unconscionable, the position in relation to the Second Renewal of the Shops 1 and 2 Lease is different.
Each of the Second to Fifth Gomax Representations was conveyed and was misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive Gomax.
But those misrepresentations and the circumstances in which those representations were made (e.g.

Dukemaster not having obtained any or any appropriate valuation evidence or advice in relation to the market rental for Shops 1 and 2 for the annual period from 23 January 2007) are only part of the picture.

When the representations did not achieve Dukemaster's desired result (a lease at $96,000), Dukemaster embarked on conduct in relation to the Second Renewal which, in all the circumstances, was unconscionable in contravention of s 51AC of the TPA by reason of: the 3 January 2007 letter was the first notification to Gomax of the $96,000 Rent notwithstanding that: 
(a) Gomax had confirmed it wished to exercise the option for an additional term on 21 August 2006: see [244] above;
 
(b) Dukemaster had decided on the $96,000 Rent by no later than 23 August 2006 but took no step to advise Gomax until 3 January 2007: see [89], [92] and [247] above; and
 
(c) in October 2006, when Gomax contacted Dukemaster and asked them for a response to the 21 August 2006 letter, Dukemaster not only told Gomax that it "did not have any idea how much rent they should charge" (which was untrue) but Dukemaster did not respond to a reasonable request from Gomax to be told as soon as it could.

Dukemaster not only knew and did not tell Gomax, it made false statements to Gomax;
 the 3 January 2007 letter required a response within seven days at a time when independent advice was not readily available and when there was no explanation provided by Dukemaster to justify the limited time in which Gomax could respond; in late January 2007, Dukemaster offered Gomax a longer term lease if it agreed to the $96,000 Rent and then sought to have Mrs Ho sign up to the new terms on a copy of the 3 January 2007 letter all at a time when Dukemaster knew the Boxcar business was not going well and Gomax were trying to sell the business: see [253] above; on 22 March 2007, Dukemaster sent the 22 March 2007 letter withdrawing the offer of a new lease with the additional term: see [258] above; on 17 April 2007 and contrary to prior practice (see [261] above), Dukemaster's lawyers sending a letter of demand to Gomax for non payment of rent and threatening repossession of the premises; in August 2007, Dukemaster hand delivered lease documents for signing by Gomax with rent in accordance with the Sheehan rental determination but excluding any additional term: see [263] above; in August 2007, Dukemaster refused to resurrect the previous offer of an additional term despite being asked to do so by Gomax for the stated reason that because Gomax had refused to take up the lease at $96,000, Dukemaster was not going to extend the lease any more to Gomax: see [263] above; and Dukemaster conveying the Second to Fifth Gomax Representations, some in the circumstances outlined above in English when it knew Mrs Ho had little or no ability to speak or read English.
The conduct just described was deliberate and directed at achieving one objective --- rent of $96,000, which was substantially in excess of the market rent.
And then when that objective was threatened and ultimately not achieved, Dukemaster's deliberate conduct continued to be irreconcilable with what is right or reasonable.
For those reasons, that conduct was unfair and unreasonable and contravened s 51AC of the TPA.

(4) RELIEF 
 Again, in relation to these contraventions of the TPA, it is appropriate that there be declarations and injunctions.
In addition, pursuant to s 87(1A) (read with s 87(1AA)) of the TPA, the Respondents should refund to Gomax the amount of rent they were overcharged totalling $16,882.
The sum of $16,882 is calculated by subtracting the market rent from the rent in fact they paid from 23 January 2004 up to and including 22 January 2007.

For the reasons given earlier (see [142] above), on the question of interest, under s 51A of the FCA, Gomax was entitled to interest on those amounts from the date of payment up to and including 28 February 2009.
That amount of interest is $5,427.
The ACCC also sought interest on the total amount from 1 March 2009.
For the reasons given earlier (see [143] above), the form of the order sought by the ACCC is not appropriate.
Instead, the Respondents should pay Gomax interest on the amounts overpaid (see [302] above) from and including 1 March 2009.
If the parties are unable to quantify that amount, they may have the matter re-listed.
That leaves one final amount --- the ACCC sought an order that the Respondents pay a further $1,650 for the valuation for the rental for the Third Shop 4 Lease.
I do not consider that this is an amount that Gomax should recover from the Respondents.
As with Mr Tan and Mrs Lai, Gomax exercised a legal right available to it.
Contrary to the ACCC's submissions that was necessary and, moreover, it achieved its objective.

F. SHOP 8 --- BAISO CAFÉ 
(1) FACTS 
 (A) Up to 2004
 Baiso Japanese Café is in Shop 8 in the Food Court.
The business is owned by Mr Mei who works full time in the café as a cook and is responsible for managing the business.
He has owned and operated the business since July 2004.
Mr Mei was born in China.
He arrived in Australia in 1990 on a student visa and for the next five years worked as a cook in several take away shops in Melbourne.
From 1995 to 2000, he managed a Chinese take away shop in the Chadstone Shopping Centre called "Sizzling Wok".
For the last 12 months of that period, he owned a 30% share in that business.
Mr Mei's English is limited.
He speaks Mandarin.
Mr Mei gave evidence through an interpreter.
Mr Mei is married to Xin Lei Sheng ("Mrs Sheng").
His wife also works in the café as a cook.
Mrs Sheng left China in 1995 to join her husband and arrived in Australia together with their only daughter, Michelle Mei ("Ms Mei").
On her arrival in Australia, she worked in a chocolate factory and then for a food company for three years.

At the end of that period, Mrs Sheng worked in another take away food shop called "Asian Gourmet" in the Chadstone Shopping Centre and other take away food shops in the Southland Shopping Centre where she made sushi.
Mrs Sheng speaks fluent Mandarin but her English is limited.
Mrs Sheng gave evidence through an interpreter.
Their daughter, Ms Mei, is currently 24 years old.
Until late 2006, Ms Mei also worked in the café.
She currently works full time at Monash University.
She speaks English and Mandarin and sometimes translates and interprets for her parents on important matters.

Mr Mei gave evidence that in April 2004 (before concluding the negotiations to buy the business then being operated at Shop 8), he and the existing owner of O Bento met Ms Wong at which time he outlined his experience to Ms Wong and, in response to him asking Ms Wong for a new lease with a five year term and a five year option, Ms Wong responded by saying that there would be no more five by five leases, the new lease would be three by three, she could not offer a new lease and that if the business did well, Dukemaster would offer a new lease.
Ms Wong's evidence was that Mr Mei spoke about his previous experience and the fact that he intended to change the name of the business.
Ms Wong did not refer to Mr Mei asking any question about a new lease.
I accept Mr Mei's version of what transpired.
The fact that Mr Mei was looking for a new lease with a longer term and an option to renew was commercially sensible.
The existing lease only had two years left to run.
Moreover, Mr Mei was not cross examined about the contents of the conversation and Ms Wong (who was in Court throughout Mr Mei's evidence) did not contradict Mr Mei's recounting of what transpired.
In June 2004, Mr Mei negotiated to purchase the "O Bento" business then operating from Shop 8.
Mr Mei gave evidence that he believed Ms Wong when she said that if the business did well, she would grant him a new lease and he was confident that he and his wife could do well.
The transfer of the existing lease was signed on 30 June 2004.
The lease was a five year lease due to expire on 27 July 2007.
To the extent that the leasing history of the tenancy was not in dispute, it is summarised in Annexure A. Baiso started trading on 1 July 2004.

(B) 2006 - 2008
 Towards the end of 2006 or early 2007, Mr Mei was aware that he would have to ask Dukemaster for a new lease.
Consistent with the terms of the existing lease, the rent and promotional fee payable to Dukemaster had increased to $5,710.34 a month.
At that time, the annual rent component was $63,813.76 (excluding GST).
Baiso could not afford to pay a much higher rent.

Again, despite Dukemaster having held the 22 and 23 August 2006 meetings and having determined the rent for Shop 8 at that time (see [89] to [100] above), in contravention of s 16 of the RTRA Dukemaster took no step to contact Mr Mei to discuss granting him a new lease or advising him of the new rent.
I deal with this issue in further detail below.

On 10 March 2007, Mr Mei (with the assistance of his daughter) wrote to Dukemaster in the following terms: 
Dear Dukemaster Pty Ltd:
 
 
I am the owner of Baiso Japanese Café in the Paramount Retail Centre food court.
I am aware that our lease ends on 28 July 2007, I would like [to] continue by signing a new lease with Dukemaster.
Can you please arrange a time for a discussion at your convenience.
Thank you very much.
In April or May 2007, Mr Mei met Ms Wong and Mr Sant to discuss the new lease for Baiso.
The fact of the meeting was not in dispute ("the May 2007 conversation").
Mr Mei's evidence was that Ms Wong and Mr Mei spoke in Mandarin.
Ms Wong and Mr Sant spoke in English.
Mr Sant did not speak Mandarin.

Ms Wong offered Mr Mei a three by three year lease, first year rent of $80,000 per annum plus GST with CPI rent increases after each year, market rent review at the end of the third year and no more promotional fee.
Mr Mei said the rent was too high and that it would put too much pressure on him.
He asked for a lower rent.
Ms Wong responded saying that she was the manager, not the boss and that Ms Wong would have to take it to the bosses.
Mr Mei reiterated that the length of the lease was acceptable but not the rent.
Mr Mei asked Ms Wong to write the new rent down so that he could have a comparison.
Ms Wong then did some calculations on a piece of paper which she gave to Mr Mei - existing monthly rent was $5,995.84 and the future rent was $7,333.33.

During the course of this meeting, Mr Mei said that Ms Wong sought to compare the rent for Shop 8 with the rents for other shops in the Food Court and said that the rent for Shop 8 was very similar or comparable to that in the Target Centre or QV Centre.
Mr Mei was not cross examined about the contents of his evidence.
Ms Wong (who sat in Court during Mr Mei's evidence) did not contradict Mr Mei's evidence.
She recalled Mr Mei asking for a lower rent.
The lack of contradiction is not surprising given the contents of subsequent correspondence: see [317] below.
Mr Mei discussed the rent increase with his wife.

On 16 May 2007, a letter was sent to Dukemaster signed by Mr Mei in the following terms: 
Since our discussion on 10 th May, both my wife and I are very grateful for your help and consideration in many aspects of our business.

As for the topics raised in this meeting, we have decided to agree on the following:
 
 
1.

Rent will increase in accordance with CPI
 
2.

Promotion fees will be cancelled
 
3.
Rent period will by 3 by 3.

However, there are several issues that we'd still like to raise with the shopping centre:
 
 
1.
Since we purchased the business in 2004, rent has increased by 5% per annum.
At the same time, due to the shortage of rain and water, prices for nearly all of the raw materials we use have increased as well.
Chilli prices have sky rocketed to $50/kg, snow peas to $16/kg, prices of egg (sic) have increased from $22/box to $40, and chicken meat have increased from $4.2/kg to $6.2/kg.
However, we have kept our selling prices steady throughout this time.
Not that we don't want to increase, but due to the concern that our customer flow is very limited and competition in the area is very fierce.
Under this sort of circumstances, the increase of rent to $88,000 per annum including GST will be too much for us to handle.
Can I please invite the shopping centre management to re-consider our difficulties and give us a more acceptable rent rate?
In regards to the offer made by the shopping centre to lease to us the idle shop space near the lift, after careful consideration, we have decided not to accept this offer.
The main reason is that we have to pay an extra $20,000 of rent per annum plus renovation costs.
We are not confident that we will be able to make as much profit as the costs.
Therefore, we would like to pass the offer on and sincerely thank you for your support and consideration.
I am looking forward to your reply.
During cross examination, another version of this letter was shown to Mr Mei and his daughter.
The other version contained more sophisticated language and was more structured.
The author of the letter was not established although Mr Mei's daughter believed she might have sent the draft by email to her father.
Notwithstanding the differences in language and structure, the letter was substantially in the same terms as the letter ultimately sent to Dukemaster: see [315].

Dukemaster responded on 26 June 2007 when Mr Sant hand delivered a letter to Mr Mei from Dukemaster's lawyers in the following terms: 
...
 
 
We refer to your letter of the 16 May 2007 to our client, and note that you have rejected our client's offer of a New Lease for the above premises for a term of three (3) years and an option of a further term of three (3) years at the commencing rent of $80,000.00 per annum plus GST.

We note that as you have rejected our client's offer, you will now have the following two (2) options at the expiration of the current term on the 27 July 2007:
 
 
 Option 1: Continue to occupy the premises pursuant to the Holding Over provision under Clause 3.2 of the Lease, i.e.

on a month-to-month basis at the rent of $80,000.00 per annum plus GST on or from the 28 July 2007 and otherwise on the same terms and conditions as the current Lease; or
 
 
 Option 2 : Vacate the premises at the expiration of the Lease, i.e.
on or before the 27 July 2007.

Should you take Option 2, we refer to you to Clause 11 of the Lease which requires you to remove your installations / fittings and make good any damages or disfigurements caused to the premises and return the premises to the Landlord in a condition as at the Commencement Date, fair wear and tear excepted.
We will also advise the Landlord to contact you to arrange for a final inspection to be conducted on the premises.
Please advise us as soon as possible whether or not you will take Option 1 or Option 2 so that we can advise our client accordingly.
We await your prompt response.
Mr Mei had difficulty understanding the letter.
He understood that the rent was to be $80,000.
He asked his daughter to translate the letter for him.
Mr Mei was shocked.
He did not believe that he had rejected the offer of a new lease.
He knew he had disagreed with the rent but was waiting for Ms Wong to come back to him after she had spoken to her boss about the rent.
As his letter of 16 May stated, he wanted a meeting to discuss the rent.
Mr Mei showed the letter to his wife.
Neither option in the letter was acceptable to him.
However, he knew he had to get a lease to protect his business.
Mr Mei decided that even if he had a rent he could not afford, it was a lesser evil than the other option given to him in the letter --- lose his business and then possibly his house.
Mr Mei asked his daughter to respond by email to Dukemaster's lawyers.

A letter was sent by his daughter in the following terms: 
Dear Mr Lim
 
 
My name is Michelle Mei and I write in regards to the letter we received from you on 26 June 2007, titled Lease: Dukemaster Pty Ltd to MEI.
It was stated in the letter that because Mei rejected Dukemaster's offer of a New Lease that he is now provided with two options at the expiration of the current lease on 27 July 2007.

I do not know if you have a copy of the letter Mei wrote to Dukemaster on 16 May 2007, or maybe you can contact your client to get a copy, but there was nothing in that original letter that insinuated in anyway that Mei was going to reject the offer.

The letter was set out in a format that some agreed points and some disagreed points and the main objective of that letter was to arrange a one-on-one meeting with Dukemaster to discuss about the lease.

Up until now, Baiso Japanese Café has not received anything in writing that resembled a lease, all that was said previously was the rent was to increase to $80,000, but no official lease was ever provided.

Therefore, I think a misunderstanding has occurred regarding Mei's letter to Patricia Wong on 16 May 2007, and I'd appreciate it if you could contact your client and notify them that the offer of a New Lease was never rejected by Baiso in anyway.
In the meantime, Mei is hoping that he will be able to receive a copy of the New Lease so that he can have someone translate it for him to Mandarine (sic).
Mei's English ability is very limited, and that might have been a vital reason that caused this misunderstanding and confusion.
If it's possible, Baiso would like to arrange for a meeting with Patricia Wong in the presence of the Small Business Commissions in the near future.
Your help and understanding on this matter will be very much appreciated.

Regards
 
 
Michelle
 
Baiso Japanese Café 
 
 Several days later, Mr Sant came to Shop 8 and collected Mr Mei to attend a meeting with Ms Wong.
The meeting was attended by Ms Wong, Mr Sant and Mr Mei.
It lasted for about 1 hour.
Again, during the meeting, Mr Mei and Ms Wong spoke in Mandarin and Mr Sant and Ms Wong spoke in English.

Ms Wong told Mr Mei that the tone taken by its lawyers in the letter dated 26 June 2007 was not representative of Dukemaster's attitude and that Dukemaster was not the sort of landlord who would just kick a tenant out.
Ms Wong also told Mr Mei that he should not pay attention to what was said by the other tenants.
During the course of this meeting, Mr Mei said he would accept the lease and the $80,000 rent.
On 2 July 2007, Mr Sant hand delivered to Mr Mei another letter from Dukemaster's solicitors.
The letter enclosed a copy of the new lease together with other documents.

At about this time, Mr Mei became aware that three other tenants in the Food Court were about to renew their leases and had decided to go to a rent determination rather than pay the rent proposed by Dukemaster.
One of the shops, East on Paramount, was larger than the shop operated by Mr Mei and in a similar location.
Mr Mei decided to wait until these rental determinations were completed before he signed the lease for Baiso.
Mr Mei did not think that $80,000 was the market rent.
Mrs Sheng's sworn viva voce evidence was that at least on two occasions after receiving the 2 July 2007 letter, she discussed the proposed lease with Ms Wong.
At least one of these conversations occurred about two days before the lease was due to expire.
Mrs Sheng's evidence about the timing and contents of these conversations was not altogether clear.
At one point, Mrs Sheng admitted that it was possible that at least some of the matters allegedly discussed post 2 July 2007 could have been discussed as early as April 2007.

However, it remained her uncontested evidence that at some point after she received the new lease, she discussed a number of matters with Ms Wong, including that she believed the rent was too high and that she was concerned that the new lease did not say that Baiso would be the only Japanese take away restaurant in the Food Court (the "July 2007 conversation").
Ms Wong denied that any oral conversation occurred regarding the lease after 2 July 2007.
I reject Ms Wong's denial.

Counsel for the Respondents did not challenge Mrs Sheng's evidence that there was at least one occasion where Mrs Sheng asked Ms Wong for 60 days to sign the lease and Mrs Wong refused, saying that someone else was waiting to take the premises if Mr Mei and Mrs Sheng did not sign the lease Moreover, the Respondents' Counsel did not challenge Mrs Sheng's statement that "we had many discussions, we didn't only have one discussion, we had many discussions and definitely we had discussion that last time" (being where the conditions of the new lease were discussed).
Mr Mei signed the new lease on 25 or 26 July 2007, two days before the lease was to expire.
A week later, Mr Mei learned that the rental determinations had been completed and that the rent for East on Paramount (a larger shop) was about $40,000 per year.
Mrs Sheng's sworn viva voce evidence was that she had a discussion with Ms Wong about the "rental determinations".
The precise circumstances in which this conversation took place were not altogether clear.
Mrs Sheng's evidence was that after she became aware of the rental determination for East on Paramount she approached Ms Wong about lowering the rent and Ms Wong refused.
Counsel for the Respondents did not challenge Mrs Sheng's evidence.
(2) CONDUCT MISLEADING OR DECEPTIVE OR LIKELY TO MISLEAD OR DECEIVE?
The ACCC had two complaints.
Each complaint dealt with separate representations.
Although some of the representations contain common elements, each must be considered separately because each is said to constitute a separate contravention of s 52 of the TPA.

(A) MAY 2007 CONVERSATION
 First, the ACCC contends that the contents of the May 2007 conversation were misleading and deceptive because, by the May 2007 conversation, Dukemaster represented to Mr Mei that: the proposed $80,000 rent plus GST ("the $80,000 Rent") for the Second Shop 8 Lease was reasonable and was the market value ("the First Mei Representation"); and it had a reasonable basis for expressing its opinion that the $80,000 Rent was reasonable and was the market value ("the Second Mei Representation"), 
when, in fact, the $80,000 Rent was not reasonable and Dukemaster did not have a reasonable basis for expressing its opinion that the $80,000 Rent was reasonable and the market value.

Moreover, the ACCC submitted that Dukemaster had not obtained appropriate valuation advice or evidence in relation to the market rental for Shop 8 from 28 July 2007 to 27 July 2008 and that if it had done so, the market value was significantly less than $80,000 and was approximately $40,250 plus GST.
Again, the two questions arise in the context of s 52 of the TPA.
(1) Was each representation conveyed and (2) if yes to (1), was it misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive?
First and Second Mei Representations Conveyed?
It must be recalled that the Respondent's Counsel did not seek to cross examine Mr Mei about the contents of the May 2007 conversation: see [314] above.
Each of the First and Second Mei Representations was conveyed by the May 2007 conversation: see [314] above.

First and Second Mei Representations Misleading or Deceptive or Likely to Mislead or Deceive
 Taken as a whole, the evidence reveals no basis for Dukemaster holding a belief that the rent for Shop 8 was "reasonable" and "the market value".

Dukemaster had not obtained valuation advice or evidence in relation to the market rental for Shop 8 for the period from 28 July 2007 to 27 July 2008 that provided a basis for it holding a belief that the rental it was seeking for Shop 8 was "reasonable" and "the market value": see [88] to [111] above.
Conduct Induce or Capable of Inducing Error?

As explained earlier (see [10(1)] above), if the evidence shows that the opinion expressed by Dukemaster lacked any or any adequate basis, the conduct contravenes s 52 of the TPA only if that conduct induces or is capable of inducing error.
If the rent was in fact "reasonable" and / or "the market value", then it would not be shown that the conduct complained of by the ACCC could induce or would be capable of inducing error.

In relation to Shop 8, I consider that the conduct complained of is misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive because it is much more probable than not that the $80,000 Rent was not "reasonable" and / or "market value".
I have addressed the evidence of Mr Sheehan above see: [71] to [83].
In relation to Shop 8, Mr Sheehan was asked to express an opinion on the current market rent of Shop 8 for the annual period commencing on 28 July 2007.

Against the background set out in the earlier analysis (see [71] to [85] above]) in dealing with Shop 8, Mr Sheehan noted that the previous rent for the shop for the period from 28 July 2006 to 27 July 2007 was $63,813.81 per annum (excluding GST).

Shop 8 he described as "situated within the eastern section of the Little Bourke Street level adjacent to the double access doors leading to the loading dock and the garbage area" and "[i]n comparison to other food service outlets within the food court it has a smaller than average frontage of about 6m".

As the summary of evidence records (see Annexure C) Mr Sheehan expressed that the market rent for Shop 8 for the annual period from 28 July 2007 was $40,250 (excluding GST), not $80,000 (excluding GST).
The rent proposed to be charged by Dukemaster ($80,000 excluding GST) is more than 95% above the market rent identified by Mr Sheehan ($40,250 excluding GST).

In the absence of positive evidence from the Respondents that the market value of the rent for Shop 8 for the annual period from 28 July 2007 of $80,000 (excluding GST) was "reasonable" or "market value", I can only conclude that the First and Second Mei Representations were misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive Mr Mei.
The $80,000 Rent (excluding GST) was neither "reasonable" nor "the market value".

(B) JULY 2007 CONVERSATION
 Secondly, the ACCC contends that the contents of the July 2007 conversation were misleading and deceptive because, by the July 2007 conversation, Dukemaster represented to Mr Mei that: the $80,000 Rent was reasonable and the market value ("the Third Mei Representation"); and it had a reasonable basis for expressing its opinion that the $80,000 Rent was reasonable and the market value ("the Fourth Mei Representation"), 
when, in fact, the $80,000 Rent was not reasonable and Dukemaster did not have a reasonable basis for expressing its opinion that the $80,000 Rent was reasonable and the market value.

Again, the ACCC submitted that Dukemaster had not obtained appropriate valuation advice or evidence in relation to the market rental for Shop 8 from 28 July 2007 to 27 July 2008 and that if it had done so, the market value was significantly less than $80,000 and was approximately $40,250 plus GST.
Again, the two questions arise in the context of s 52 of the TPA.
(1) Was each representation conveyed and (2) if yes to (1), was it misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive?
Third and Fourth Mei Representations Conveyed?
I reject the ACCC's contention that each of the Third and Fourth Mei Representations was conveyed by the July 2007 conversation: see [322] above.
The evidence did not disclose that Ms Wong made those representations during those conversations.
The claim fails at the first hurdle.

(3) UNCONSCIONABLE CONDUCT 
 The ACCC also alleged that Dukemaster's conduct was unconscionable within the meaning of s 51AC(1)(a) of the TPA.
Those allegations concern the "negotiation" of the Second Shop 8 Lease.
A summary of the relevant legal principles is set out in Section B above.

Again, given my earlier findings in relation to s 52 of the TPA, and subject to the question of the appropriateness of any declarations and injunctions, a contravention of s 51AC would not otherwise add to or alter the other relief available: see generally Part VI of the TPA.

(A) "NEGOTIATION" OF SECOND SHOP 8 LEASE
 The ACCC's complaint was that Dukemaster's conduct in relation to the negotiation of the Second Shop 8 Lease (see Annexure A) was unconscionable within the meaning of s 51AC(1)(a) of the TPA by reason of a number of facts.
As I said earlier (see [127]), s 51AC of the TPA does not require resolution of whether the factors listed by the ACCC are proved or not proved.
The question is whether the supply by Dukemaster of lease premises to Mr Mei was, in all the circumstances, unconscionable.
In assessing that question, the ACCC contends that the matters listed in s 51AC(3)(a), (c), (d), (j) and (k) are relevant.
In all the circumstances, I consider that Dukemaster's conduct in relation to the negotiation of the Second Shop 8 Lease was unconscionable.

Each of the First and Second Mei Representations were conveyed and were not only misleading and deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive (see [325] --- [334] above) but were conveyed in circumstances where: Dukemaster knew from the outset that Mr Mei wanted a new lease: see [309] above; the representations were intended by Dukemaster to secure a new lease at a rental for which there was no basis beyond Dukemaster's decision to seek the amount stated; they were in breach of s 16 of the RTRA, that where a retail premises lease does not have an option under the lease to renew the lease for a further term (as was the case with the Baiso Lease), Dukemaster:
 
... must, at least 6 months but no more than 12 months before the lease term ends, give written notice to the tenant -
